  3. Hair loss spares the sides and back of the head
  4. Loss of all body hair
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C

 

Alopecia totalis (1-B): Characterized by complete or nearly complete loss of scalp hair.

 

Alopecia universalis (2-D): Most extensive form, with complete loss of all body hair, including eyebrows and eyelashes.

 

Ophiasis (3-A): Distinctive pattern of alopecia along the scalp margins, especially occipital and temporal areas.

 

Sisaipho pattern (4-C): Reverse ophiasis pattern, where hair loss spares the margins, especially sides and back of head.

 

Educational Objective:


Pattern recognition in alopecia is crucial for diagnosis. Alopecia areata presents with various clinical patterns—totalis (scalp), universalis (entire body), ophiasis (margins), and sisaipho (sparing margins)—each with diagnostic and prognostic implications.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child has sustained an injury and his x-ray is shown. Identify the best choice which marks the delayed set of complications seen in this injury.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Damage to ulnar nerve, non-union

 

  • Ulnar nerve injury is a more common complication in fractures involving the elbow, particularly with fractures around the medial epicondyle or supracondylar fractures. 
  • The ulnar nerve runs near the medial aspect of the elbow and can be injured by direct trauma or stretching during the fracture.
  • Non-union refers to the failure of a fracture to heal properly, and it is a well-documented complication in paediatric fractures, particularly in the supracondylar humeral fractures when there is significant displacement or poor alignment of the fracture.
  • The combination of ulnar nerve damage and non-union is a classic delayed complication seen in fractures around the elbow in children, making this the most likely set of complications.
  • Damage to the ulnar nerve and non-union is a well-known delayed complication of elbow fractures, particularly those involving the humerus in children.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Median nerve, Cubitus valgus:

 

  • The median nerve is commonly affected in injuries involving the distal humerus or fractures of the forearm, but it is less likely to be associated with delayed complications from elbow fractures. 
  • On the other hand, cubitus valgus (an outward angulation of the forearm relative to the upper arm) is a common deformity after a supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
  • Cubitus valgus is typically the result of incorrect healing or malalignment after an elbow fracture, especially if there’s a growth plate involvement.
  • However, while cubitus valgus is a delayed complication of certain fractures, median nerve injury is less commonly associated with the delayed complications from elbow fractures in children.
  • While cubitus valgus could be a late complication, median nerve injury is not the most common delayed complication of this injury in a child.

 

Option C. Radial nerve, Myositis ossificans:

 

  • The radial nerve is typically involved in fractures of the midshaft of the humerus or elbow, but radial nerve injury is less commonly seen as a delayed complication compared to ulnar nerve injury in elbow fractures.
  • Myositis ossificans is the formation of bone tissue inside muscle after trauma. It typically occurs after muscle contusions or direct muscle injury rather than bone fractures. 
  • It is often seen in the thigh or upper arm but can also occur after a fracture in the vicinity of muscle groups, particularly when there is significant soft tissue injury.
  • While both radial nerve injury and myositis ossificans can be complications following trauma, they are less specific to elbow fractures in children.
  • Although both radial nerve injury and myositis ossificans can occur, they are not the most common delayed complications of elbow fractures in children compared to ulnar nerve damage and non-union.

 

Option D. Non-union and cubitus varus:

 

  • Non-union (failure of the fracture to heal) is indeed a common delayed complication of fractures, especially in the elbow region. 
  • However, cubitus varus (an inward angulation of the forearm relative to the upper arm) is a deformity often seen after an elbow fracture, particularly when there is improper alignment during healing. 
  • It can occur after a supracondylar fracture or distal humeral fracture.
  • Cubitus varus is often considered a cosmetic deformity but can affect function if severe. It results from malunion, where the bone heals in an incorrect position.
  • Although cubitus varus can occur as a delayed complication, it is more associated with malalignment during the healing process rather than being a primary concern along with non-union.
  • While non-union and cubitus varus can occur as delayed complications, the combination of ulnar nerve damage and non-union is a more accurate and common delayed complication in pediatric elbow fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to ulnar nerve, non-union is a well-established delayed complication, particularly in pediatric supracondylar fractures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who was a known case of Cushing’s disease underwent TSS 7 years ago. He is currently on prednisolone. In the last 2 months he has been suffering from increasing headaches and skin lesions as shown below. S. ACTH is elevated and MRI of the brain does not reveal any pituitary abnormality. What is the most appropriate next step in the diagnostic workup?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior petrosal sinus sampling

 

  • Recurrent ACTH-dependent Cushing’s with elevated ACTH and no visible pituitary mass requires localization. 
  • Inferior petrosal sinus sampling (IPSS) helps distinguish pituitary from ectopic sources. 
  • It is the gold standard for differentiating Cushing’s disease from ectopic ACTH production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FDG PET: Used if IPSS shows ectopic source; not initial step.

 

Option C. Low dose dexamethasone suppression test: Confirms hypercortisolism but not source.

 

Option D. Chest X-ray: Non-specific and insensitive for ectopic ACTH sources.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In ACTH-dependent Cushing’s without pituitary lesion on MRI, IPSS is essential to confirm a pituitary vs ectopic source.

questions.text: First permanent teeth to erupt in socket of temporary teeth?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Permanent Central Incisor

 

Permanent Central Incisor because it is the first permanent tooth to erupt in place of a primary (temporary) tooth socket. This process is part of the mixed dentition phase, where primary teeth are gradually replaced by permanent teeth.

 

  • The first permanent teeth to erupt overall are the first molars (typically around age 6), but these do not replace any primary teeth—they erupt posterior to the last primary molar.
  • The central incisors, on the other hand, erupt into the sockets of the primary central incisors, typically around 6–7 years of age, making them the first permanent teeth to erupt into the position of a primary tooth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Permanent 1st Molar: This is the first permanent tooth to erupt overall, but it does not erupt in a socket of a temporary tooth; it erupts posterior to the deciduous teeth.

 

Option C. Permanent Lateral Incisor:  These erupt after the central incisors, typically around 7–8 years of age, so they are not the first to erupt in the place of a primary tooth.

 

Option D. Permanent Canine: These erupt even later, around 9–12 years of age, and therefore are not the first permanent teeth to replace primary teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Permanent central incisors are the first permanent teeth to erupt in the sockets of primary (temporary) teeth.

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bonney’s Myomectomy Clamp

 

  • Bonney’s Myomectomy Clamp is a self-retaining clamp designed for hemostasis during myomectomy.
  • It has broad curved blades that help in compressing the myometrium, thereby reducing intraoperative blood loss during fibroid enucleation.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Green-Armytage Forceps: Used to clamp the uterine edges during cesarean section but not for myomectomy.


Option C. Teale Vulsellum Forceps: Has multiple teeth and is used for grasping the cervix during hysterectomy or D&E procedures, not for myometrial hemostasis.


Option D. Hulka Tenaculum: A single-tooth or double-tooth instrument used to stabilize the cervix during hysteroscopy or IUD insertion, not for fibroid removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bonney’s Myomectomy Clamp is specifically designed for hemostasis in myomectomy surgeries.
  • Green-Armytage Forceps → Used in cesarean sections for uterine hemostasis.
  • Teale Vulsellum Forceps → Used for grasping the cervix.
  • Hulka Tenaculum → Used for cervical manipulation during hysteroscopy or IUD placement.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male diagnosed with squint presents to the ophthalmology department for a routine check-up. On examination, the medial rectus muscle is found to be affected, as seen in the given CT scan. At which level does the nerve supplying the marked structure arise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red nucleus

 

  • The marked muscle in the CT scan is the medial rectus muscle.
  • The medial rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (CN III).
  • The oculomotor nerve nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain, close to the red nucleus.
  • Lesions affecting this area can result in medial rectus palsy, leading to inability to adduct the eye and manifesting as a lateral squint (exotropia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: Incorrect.

 

  • The subthalamic nucleus is part of the basal ganglia circuitry and is involved in movement regulation, not in eye movement control.
  • Damage here causes hemiballismus (involuntary flinging movements), not eye muscle paralysis.

 

Option C. Decussation of the pyramidal tract: Incorrect.

 

  • The pyramidal tract controls voluntary motor function but does not directly influence extraocular muscles.
  • It is located at the medullary level, not the midbrain where the oculomotor nucleus is found.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: Incorrect.

 

  • The inferior olivary nucleus is involved in cerebellar coordination and motor learning.
  • It has no role in supplying the medial rectus or controlling extraocular muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The medial rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which arises at the level of the superior colliculus, near the red nucleus.
  • Damage to the oculomotor nerve can cause medial rectus palsy, leading to an inability to adduct the eye (exotropia).
  • The red nucleus is a crucial midbrain structure related to CN III, while subthalamic, pyramidal, and olivary structures have no direct role in extraocular muscle control.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with moderate major depressive disorder has been on escitalopram for the past 3 months. While his mood symptoms have significantly improved, he now complains of difficulty achieving orgasm and reduced libido. He is concerned about these sexual side effects and requests a change in medication. Which of the following antidepressants is most appropriate to switch to in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agomelatine

 

  • The patient is experiencing sexual side effects, a common issue with SSRIs like escitalopram. 
  • Since his depressive symptoms are improving, but sexual dysfunction is distressing, switching to an antidepressant with minimal sexual side effects is appropriate. 
  • Agomelatine, a melatonergic agonist and 5-HT2C antagonist, is not associated with significant sexual dysfunction, making it a suitable alternative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duloxetine: An SNRI, which, like SSRIs, may also cause sexual side effects, though possibly to a lesser extent.

 

Option B. Venlafaxine: Another SNRI, also commonly associated with sexual dysfunction, particularly at higher doses.

 

Option D. Clomipramine: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) with strong serotonergic action, and significant sexual side effects as well as anticholinergic burden.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agomelatine is a melatonin receptor agonist (MT1, MT2) and 5-HT₂C antagonist, used in depression.
  • It has minimal sexual side effects due to a non-serotonergic mechanism, making it ideal for patients with SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction.
  • Also improves sleep-wake rhythm disturbances in depression, but requires LFT monitoring due to rare hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and palpitations. Examination reveals a loud S1, opening snap, and a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex. ECG is done and it is shown below. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrates moderate mitral stenosis with a mean gradient of 8 mmHg. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anticoagulation with warfarin

 

  • The ECG likely shows atrial fibrillation (AF), a common complication of mitral stenosis. 
  • Warfarin is indicated to prevent thromboembolism in MS with AF. 
  • DOACs are not approved for use in moderate to severe MS or in the presence of mechanical heart valves. 
  • Valvotomy decisions require assessment of Wilkins score and TEE to rule out LA thrombus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balloon mitral valvotomy: Cannot be done without assessment of valve morphology and exclusion of LA thrombus.

 

Option C. Mitral valve replacement: Reserved for cases unsuitable for valvotomy or with severe calcification.

 

Option D. Start aspirin and beta-blocker:  Symptomatic relief alone is inadequate in the presence of AF and MS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis with AF, warfarin is the anticoagulant of choice; DOACs are contraindicated due to lack of efficacy data and risk.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding emergency contraception are true?

 

Statements:
 

  1. Levonorgestrel (Plan B single step) is effective up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse.
  2. Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used within 5 days for emergency contraception.
  3. The Yuzpe method consists of Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg taken in a single dose.
  4. Copper IUDs can be inserted within 7 days after unprotected intercourse for emergency contraception.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2


2. Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used within 5 days for emergency contraception: True, Ulipristal (30 mg) is an emergency contraceptive that delays ovulation and is effective within 5 days of unprotected sex.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

1. Levonorgestrel (Plan B single step) is effective up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse: False, Plan B single step contains 1.5 mg of Levonorgestrel, taken as a single dose, up to 72 hours after intercourse.

 

3. The Yuzpe method consists of Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg taken in a single dose: False, The Yuzpe method consists of Ethinyl estradiol 100 µg + Levonorgestrel 0.5 mg, taken in two doses, 12 hours apart.

 

4. Copper IUDs can be inserted within7 days after unprotected intercourse for emergency contraception: False,

 

  • Copper IUDs work by preventing implantation and sperm motility.
  • They are NOT recommended for rape victims due to infection risk.
  • They can be inserted upto 5 days of unprotected intercourse

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Levonorgestrel (Plan B) is effective for up to 72h hours post-intercourse.
  • Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator effective within 5 days.
  • The Yuzpe method uses Ethinyl estradiol + Levonorgestrel, NOT just Levonorgestrel alone.
  • Copper IUDs provide long-term contraception and emergency contraception within 5 days.
  • Centchroman (Chhaya) is NOT a one-time emergency contraceptive but a regular contraceptive pill.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that began approximately 3 hours ago. Visual acuity is reduced to light perception only in the affected eye. A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is noted on examination. The anterior segment of both eyes appears normal, but fundoscopic examination of the right eye reveals a pale retina with a red lesion at the macula. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central retinal artery occlusion

 

  • The clinical picture is classic for central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) — an ophthalmic emergency marked by sudden, painless, unilateral severe vision loss. 
  • A cherry-red spot-on fundus exam is highly specific and results from contrast between the ischemic pale retina and the fovea, where the thinner retina allows the underlying choroidal circulation to show through.

 

Additional supportive findings:

 

  • Light perception only suggests severe vision loss
  • RAPD confirms significant optic pathway compromise
  • Anterior segment normal → excludes anterior causes of visual loss

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertensive retinopathy: Presents with findings such as cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages, and arteriovenous nicking, but typically causes chronic progressive visual changes, not acute loss with a cherry-red spot.

 

Option C. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy: Causes neovascularization and possible vitreous hemorrhage, but vision loss is not as abrupt and lacks the hallmark cherry-red spot.

 

Option D. Central retinal vein occlusion: Presents with painless vision loss, but fundus shows a “blood and thunder” pattern — dilated tortuous veins and retinal hemorrhages, not a pale retina with a cherry-red spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central retinal artery occlusion causes sudden, painless, and profound vision loss. Fundoscopic examination reveals a pale retina with a cherry-red spot, due to obstruction of retinal arterial blood flow and sparing of the thin foveal region.

choices.text: Liquid culture is less sensitive than CBNAAT but is utilized due to its availability.
Liquid culture yields results more rapidly than CBNAAT, expediting diagnosis.
Liquid culture can confirm TB presence and assess drug susceptibility when molecular diagnostics are not accessible.
Liquid culture serves as an initial screening method before proceeding with CBNAAT.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of progressive, localized pain in his lumbar spine. Radiographic imaging shows lytic lesions of the vertebrae, raising suspicion for extrapulmonary tuberculosis (EPTB). His physician orders a Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), which is currently unavailable. The physician decides to proceed with a liquid culture. What is the primary rationale for choosing liquid culture in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liquid culture can confirm TB presence and assess drug susceptibility when molecular diagnostics are not accessible.

 

  • In cases where CBNAAT is unavailable, liquid culture becomes a critical alternative, not only confirming the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis but also providing valuable drug susceptibility information. 
  • This is essential in managing tuberculosis effectively, particularly in detecting potential drug resistance, which guides the appropriate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liquid culture is less sensitive than CBNAAT but is utilized due to its availability: Incorrect because while liquid culture is sensitive, it is not considered less sensitive than CBNAAT; the choice is based on its availability and comprehensive diagnostic capacity.

 

Option B. Liquid culture yields results more rapidly than CBNAAT, expediting diagnosis: Incorrect as liquid culture generally takes longer to yield results compared to CBNAAT, which can provide rapid detection of tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance within hours.

 

Option D. Liquid culture serves as an initial screening method before proceeding with CBNAAT: Incorrect because liquid culture is not merely a preliminary test but a comprehensive diagnostic tool capable of providing both confirmation of tuberculosis and resistance patterns, crucial for treatment planning when CBNAAT is unavailable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Algorithm for Extra-pulmonary TB (EPTB)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with morning stiffness and pain in her hands and wrists lasting more than 1 hour for the past 3 months. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness in bilateral MCP and PIP joints. Laboratory tests reveal a negative rheumatoid factor and a positive anti-CCP. CT scan of the chest is shown. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rituximab

 

  • Despite being seronegative for rheumatoid factor, a positive anti-CCP confirms seropositive RA. 
  • The CT chest shows a usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern, which may worsen with methotrexate. 
  • Rituximab is safer in patients with RA-associated ILD, particularly with UIP, where methotrexate is contraindicated.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydroxychloroquine: Mild efficacy and not preferred in presence of ILD.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Contraindicated in ILD, especially UIP pattern, due to risk of pulmonary toxicity.

 

Option C. Leflunomide: Also associated with pulmonary toxicity and not preferred in UIP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rituximab is preferred in rheumatoid arthritis patients with UIP pattern ILD due to its safety profile compared to methotrexate and leflunomide.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. A CT scan reveals retroperitoneal hematomas. The trauma team discusses the appropriate management based on the zones of retroperitoneal trauma and the patient’s hemodynamic status. Which of the following statements regarding retroperitoneal trauma are true?

 

  1. Zone 1- injuries often involve major vascular structures and should be surgically explored.
  2. Zone 2- hematomas, if non-expanding, should be managed conservatively.
  3. Zone 3- injuries are primarily managed with external fixation or angiographic embolization.
  4. Mattox maneuver involves mobilization of the ascending colon to expose the inferior vena cava (IVC).
  5. All Zone 2 injuries require immediate surgical exploration.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Zone 1 injuries involve major vascular structures and require surgical exploration.

 

  • This zone contains the aorta, inferior vena cava (IVC), and pancreas.
  • Due to high likelihood of vascular damage and hemodynamic instability, surgical intervention is necessary.

 

2. Zone 2 hematomas should be managed conservatively unless expanding.

 

  • Zone 2 is located in the flank regions, mainly affecting the kidneys and ureters.
  • Non-expanding hematomas do not require surgery, while expanding hematomas indicate ongoing bleeding and require surgical exploration.

 

3. Zone 3 injuries are usually associated with pelvic fractures and are managed conservatively.

 

  • Zone 3 injuries occur in the pelvic region, often due to fractures.
  • Hemorrhage control is best managed using pelvic binders, external fixation, or angiographic embolization rather than surgery.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

4. Mattox maneuver does NOT involve mobilization of the ascending colon to expose the IVC.

 

  • The Mattox maneuver involves mobilizing the left-sided abdominal viscera medially to expose the aorta, not the IVC.
  • Mobilization of the ascending colon is part of the Cattell-Braasch maneuver, used to access the IVC and right retroperitoneum.

     

5. Not all Zone 2 injuries require immediate surgical exploration.

 

  • Only expanding hematomas in Zone 2 require surgery.
  • Non-expanding hematomas can be managed conservatively without intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retroperitoneal trauma management is zone-based:
    • Zone 1 (Central): Requires immediate surgical exploration due to high vascular involvement.
    • Zone 2 (Flank/Kidney area): Conservative treatment unless the hematoma is expanding.
    • Zone 3 (Pelvis): Managed non-surgically with external fixation or embolization due to high risks of iatrogenic injury.
  • Mattox maneuver exposes the aorta, not the IVC.
  • Surgical exploration is only needed when indicated by ongoing hemorrhage or instability.

questions.text: The given image represents serum immunoglobulin levels (% of adult values) in a pediatric patient. What does ‘A’ represent in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maternal and Fetal IgG

 

  • IgG is the only immunoglobulin that crosses the placenta and provides passive immunity to the newborn.
  • At birth, IgG levels are high due to maternal IgG transfer, but soon after birth, maternal IgG is catabolized, leading to the physiological nadir (A in the image).
  • Endogenous IgG production begins within the first few weeks of life, gradually increasing over time.
  • Final adult values of all IgG subclasses are usually reached between 8-10 years of age.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. IgM: Incorrect.

 

  • IgM does not cross the placenta.
  • It starts appearing in fetal circulation from the 20th week but remains low at birth.

 

Option B. IgG: Incorrect.

 

  • The curve specifically represents the transition from maternal IgG to fetal IgG production, making "Maternal and Fetal IgG" the most accurate choice.


Option C. Maternal and Fetal IgM: Incorrect.

 

  • IgM is produced by the fetus but not transferred from the mother.
  • The image represents a decline in IgG, which is of maternal origin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Maternal IgG is transferred transplacentally and provides passive immunity to the newborn.
  • IgG levels decline after birth (physiological nadir) due to catabolism of maternal IgG, before endogenous IgG production starts.
  • Final adult levels of IgG are reached by 8-10 years of age.
  • IgM is the first immunoglobulin synthesized by the fetus but does not cross the placenta.

choices.text: Early testing and optimized treatment for infants and children
Closing the treatment gap for pregnant and breastfeeding women
Preventing new HIV infections among pregnant and breastfeeding adolescents and women
Addressing rights, gender equality, and social barriers

questions.text: Which pillar of the Global Alliance for Ending Aids in Children by 2030 most directly addresses the reduction of HIV transmission rates among newborns?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closing the treatment gap for pregnant and breastfeeding women

 

  • The pillar focusing on "Closing the treatment gap for pregnant and breastfeeding women" is crucial for reducing HIV transmission rates among newborns. 
  • This approach ensures that pregnant and breastfeeding women with HIV receive adequate antiretroviral therapy (ART), which significantly lowers the risk of mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) during pregnancy, delivery, and breastfeeding.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Early testing and optimized treatment for infants and children: While essential, this pillar primarily focuses on infants and children who have already been exposed to HIV, rather than preventing transmission. 

 

Option C. Preventing new HIV infections among pregnant and breastfeeding adolescents and women:  This pillar is also critical but focuses more broadly on preventing HIV acquisition in these populations, not directly on transmission to newborns. 

 

Option D. Addressing rights, gender equality, and social barriers:  This addresses the broader social determinants of health that impact access to care and stigma but does not directly target MTCT.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Effectively closing the treatment gap for pregnant and breastfeeding women is pivotal in reducing the incidence of mother-to-child transmission of HIV, highlighting the importance of comprehensive access to and adherence to antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy and breastfeeding to achieve an AIDS-free generation.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical manifestations are associated with zinc deficiency? 

 

  1. Sexual infantilism
  2. Loss of libido
  3. Poor wound healing
  4. Acrodermatitis enteropathica
  5. Poor weight gain
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, and 4

 

Zinc deficiency leads to multiple systemic manifestations:

 

1. Sexual infantilism: Zinc is essential for testicular development and function. Deficiency leads to hypogonadism and delayed puberty in males, presenting as sexual infantilism.

 

3. Poor wound healing: Zinc is crucial for collagen synthesis, epithelialization, and immune function. Deficiency leads to delayed wound healing and increased susceptibility to infections.

 

4. Acrodermatitis enteropathica: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder due to a mutation in the SLC39A4 gene, causing severe zinc deficiency. It presents with dermatitis of extremities and periorificial areas, alopecia, and diarrhea.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

2. Loss of libido: While zinc is important for testosterone synthesis, loss of libido is not a primary feature of zinc deficiency, especially in prepubertal children.

 

5. Poor weight gain: While growth retardation is seen, poor weight gain is not a defining feature of zinc deficiency alone. Growth failure is multifactorial, including caloric intake and other micronutrient deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zinc deficiency causes growth retardation, hypogonadism, and poor wound healing.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a severe inherited form presenting with periorificial dermatitis and diarrhea.
  • Sexual infantilism is a key feature of zinc deficiency in prepubertal males.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with recurrent painful oral ulcers, scrotal ulcers, and painful red eyes. He also has intermittent fevers and skin lesions that resemble acne. On examination, he has a positive pathergy test and bilateral pan-uveitis. Laboratory tests show elevated ESR and CRP. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Azathioprine

 

  • The clinical picture is diagnostic of Behçet’s disease with systemic and ocular involvement. 
  • Immunosuppressive therapy is needed. 
  • Azathioprine is effective in controlling pan-uveitis and preventing irreversible complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical steroids: Not adequate for systemic or ocular disease.

 

Option B. Colchicine: Used for mild mucocutaneous involvement, not pan-uveitis.

 

Option D. Apremilast: May help oral ulcers but not systemic manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Behçet’s disease with ocular and systemic features, immunosuppressive agents like azathioprine are required for disease control.

questions.text: Which of the following tumor markers is most useful for diagnosing Ewing’s sarcoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD99

 

  • CD99 is the most sensitive and commonly used immunohistochemical marker for diagnosing Ewing’s sarcoma / primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET).
  • It is a cell surface glycoprotein expressed strongly in Ewing’s sarcoma.
  • On IHC, CD99 shows strong, diffuse membranous positivity.
  • High sensitivity (almost all Ewing’s sarcoma cases show CD99 expression)
  • Specificity is not absolute, as some other small round blue cell tumors may express it too — so it’s supportive, but not definitive on its own.
  • Also, diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma is often confirmed with molecular testing for EWSR1 gene translocation, most commonly t(11;22)(q24;q12).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. S100:

 

  • S100 is a marker of neural and melanocytic differentiation.
  • Strongly expressed in:
    • Melanoma
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
    • Schwannomas and neurofibromas
    • Some chondroid tumors
  • While Ewing’s sarcoma is of neuroectodermal origin, S100 is not consistently positive in Ewing’s tumors and lacks the diagnostic utility.
  • It is not the best marker for Ewing’s sarcoma.

 

Option C. Cytokeratin:

 

  • Cytokeratin is a marker of epithelial differentiation.
  • Positive in carcinomas and some epithelioid sarcomas.
  • Ewing’s sarcoma is a mesenchymal tumor, not of epithelial origin.
  • Rarely, some Ewing’s tumors can focally express cytokeratin, but it’s not reliable or useful diagnostically in this setting.
  • It is not a helpful marker for Ewing’s.

 

Option D. Vimentin:

 

  • Vimentin is a general mesenchymal marker, expressed in many sarcomas, including:
    • Ewing’s sarcoma
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Fibrosarcoma
    • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • However, it is non-specific — almost all mesenchymal tumors express vimentin, so it doesn’t help differentiate between them.
  • While Ewing’s may be vimentin-positive, it’s not helpful for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Genetic testing for globin gene mutations

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue over several weeks. He denies bleeding, dietary restrictions, or chronic illness. His physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells on peripheral smear. His RBC count is low, and red cell distribution width (RDW) is elevated. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum ferritin studies

 

This patient presents with tiredness, microcytic hypochromic red cells, increased RDW, and low RBC count, which strongly suggests iron deficiency anemia (IDA).

 

  • Serum ferritin is the most useful and confirmatory test for diagnosing iron deficiency, as it reflects iron stores.

    In iron deficiency anemia:

    • MCV is decreased (microcytic)
    • Color (chromicity) is reduced (hypochromic)
    • RDW is increased due to variation in cell size
    • RBC count is often low
  • Serum ferritin is low in iron deficiency and is the investigation of choice to confirm the suspected diagnosis in such a clinical and hematologic setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HbA2 estimation: HbA2 estimation is used to diagnose beta-thalassemia trait, which also presents with microcytosis, but usually with normal or elevated RBC count and normal RDW. It is not the first test in someone with increased RDW and low RBC.

 

Option C. Genetic testing for globin gene mutations:Globin gene sequencing is used for confirming thalassemia syndromes, especially alpha-thalassemia, but is not required initially. It is expensive and reserved for ambiguous or severe cases.

 

Option D. Reticulocyte production index (RPI): RPI assesses the bone marrow response in anemia. It helps differentiate between hypoproliferative vs. hemolytic causes, but it is not specific to iron deficiency and does not confirm the underlying etiology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia, elevated RDW, and low RBC count, serum ferritin is the most appropriate confirmatory test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and frequent infections. He does not have a sibling. Examination reveals pallor and petechiae but no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. CBC shows pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy is done, and it is shown below. What is the most definitive treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Triple therapy with Eltrombopag

 

  • This patient has aplastic anemia and lacks a matched sibling donor.
  • In such cases, triple therapy (Eltrombopag + ATG + Cyclosporine) is the standard approach.
  • It improves outcomes when upfront allogenic transplant is not an option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allogenic Hematopoietic Bone marrow transplant: Preferred only when a matched sibling donor is available.

 

Option B. IV Immunoglobulin: Not effective in aplastic anemia.

 

Option C. High dose Corticosteroids: Not standard in aplastic anemia management.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In aplastic anemia without a matched sibling donor, immunosuppressive triple therapy with Eltrombopag is the definitive treatment.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.
Assertion is correct, but Reason is incorrect.
Reason is correct, but Assertion is incorrect.

questions.text:
Assertion-Reason 
 

Assertion: The ureter may get injured during Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (TAH) if precaution is not taken while clamping the uterine artery.


Reason: The ureter travels alongside the uterine artery and runs under the uterine artery within the broad ligament. This proximity makes it vulnerable to accidental injury during dissection and ligation of the uterine artery, especially if the ureter is not carefully identified and separated.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.

 

  • During Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (TAH), the uterine artery is ligated to control bleeding.
  • The uterine artery crosses over the ureter ("water under the bridge") in the parametrium.
  • If clamping is not done carefully, the ureter can get injured, leading to complications like ureteric obstruction or fistula formation.


Thus, the reason (anatomical relationship) correctly explains the assertion (risk of ureteric injury during TAH).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The uterine artery runs transversely, while the ureter runs in an AP direction, leading to their crossover in the parametrium.
  • This anatomical relationship increases the risk of ureteric injury during uterine artery ligation in hysterectomy.
  • Surgeons must take special care during clamping to avoid complications.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN) are true?

 

  1. CMN is typically a well-circumscribed, pigmented lesion that is often covered with hair.
  2. Large or giant CMN (>20 cm) have a lower risk of malignant melanoma compared to small CMN.
  3. Intraparenchymal melanosis is the most common neurological complication associated with CMN.
  4. Management of small CMN includes observation, while large CMN may need surgical excision.
  5. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common complication seen in CMN.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, and 4

 

Statement 1: True. CMN is a well-circumscribed, dark, often hairy lesion present at or shortly after birth.

 

Statement 3: True. Intraparenchymal melanosis is the most common neurological complication of CMN.

 

Statement 4: True. Management depends on size: small lesions may be observed; large ones often require excision due to higher risk of malignancy.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2: False. Larger CMNs (>20 cm) are associated with a higher risk of malignant melanoma, not lower.

 

Statement 5: False. While rhabdomyosarcoma is a possible complication, malignant melanoma and neurological issues (especially intraparenchymal melanosis) are more common.

 

Educational Objective:


Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) presents as a pigmented, often hairy lesion present from birth. Larger lesions carry a higher risk of malignant melanoma and neurological complications such as intraparenchymal melanosis. Management varies with size and risk of malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with COPD exacerbation is admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, altered mental status, and a PaCO₂ of 75 mmHg on arterial blood gas analysis. He is placed on mechanical ventilation. After intubation, his peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) rises significantly, and the expiratory flow does not return to baseline before the next breath on the ventilator waveform. His blood pressure drops, and he develops tachycardia. What is the most likely cause of his clinical deterioration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auto-PEEP 
 

  • Auto-PEEP (intrinsic PEEP) occurs when insufficient expiratory time leads to air trapping, particularly in obstructive lung diseases (COPD, asthma).
  • Features include: 
    • Elevated peak inspiratory pressures (PIP) and plateau pressures.
    • Expiratory flow not returning to baseline on ventilator waveform.
    • Hypotension and tachycardia due to increased intrathoracic pressure reducing venous return.


Other Options:


Option A. Tension pneumothorax: Can cause similar hemodynamic instability but would present with absent breath sounds and tracheal deviation.


Option C. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: Develops over days, not acutely post-intubation.


Option D. Mucous plug obstruction: Causes localized lung collapse (atelectasis) rather than bilateral hyperinflation.


Educational Objective:
 

In mechanically ventilated COPD patients, ensure adequate expiratory time (low respiratory rate, high inspiratory flow rates) to prevent auto-PEEP and hemodynamic instability.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male is admitted with a skin and soft tissue infection following a surgical wound complication. Empiric antibiotic therapy with a β-lactam agent is started, but the infection fails to respond. Culture of the wound exudate reveals Staphylococcus aureus, resistant to methicillin. Molecular analysis of the bacterial isolate identifies a genetic alteration that confers resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics. This resistance mechanism is primarily due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PBP alteration

 

  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) exhibits resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, including methicillin, through a well-defined genetic mechanism: PBP alteration.
  •  MRSA strains harbor the mecA gene, which encodes converts PBP to PBP2a, an altered penicillin-binding protein (PBP).
  • This altered PBP2a has a low affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics, preventing these drugs from effectively binding and inhibiting cell wall synthesis. As a result, even in the presence of methicillin or related antibiotics, the bacteria can continue to build its peptidoglycan cell wall, maintaining viability.
  • This PBP alteration is a form of target modification, and it is the central mechanism by which S. aureus demonstrates methicillin resistance. Therefore, the correct answer is PBP alteration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Efflux pump: Although efflux pumps are a resistance strategy used by various bacteria (e.g., for tetracyclines or macrolides), S. aureus does not use an efflux pump to resist methicillin. This mechanism is not relevant to methicillin resistance.

 

Option B. Antibiotic response: This term is non-specific and vague. While some bacterial responses may influence antibiotic survival, methicillin resistance in S. aureus is not due to a general antibiotic response, but rather due to a precise molecular change—PBP alteration.

 

Option D. Enzyme inactivation: Enzyme inactivation (such as beta-lactamase production) is a common mechanism in other bacteria (especially gram-negatives), where the enzyme breaks down the antibiotic. However, in MRSA, methicillin resistance is not mediated by beta-lactamase or any inactivating enzyme. Instead, the drug target itself is altered via the mecA gene, making enzyme inactivation irrelevant in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is caused by acquisition of the mecA gene, which encodes an altered penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) that has low affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics, allowing continued cell wall synthesis despite antibiotic presence.

questions.text: In the context of emerging infectious diseases, which of the following should be closely studied for its potential interspecies transmission and subsequent zoonotic outbreaks?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah Virus

 

  • Nipah Virus is a critical zoonotic disease known for its interspecies transmission between animals and humans, which can result in severe respiratory and neurological disease. 
  • Its potential for zoonotic outbreaks makes it a priority for close study and surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brucellosis: Incorrect as Brucellosis, while a zoonosis, is more associated with direct contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products rather than interspecies transmission leading to outbreaks.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B: Incorrect because Hepatitis B is a human virus transmitted via blood and bodily fluids, not typically a zoonotic disease.

 

Option D. Poliomyelitis:  Incorrect as Poliomyelitis is a human disease with no zoonotic or interspecies transmission.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nipah virus is a high-priority emerging zoonotic pathogen due to its ability to transmit between species, especially from animals (e.g., fruit bats and pigs) to humans, leading to severe and often fatal respiratory and neurological illness. Its epidemic potential and high case fatality rate make it a critical target for surveillance, early detection, and intersectoral One Health approaches in public health.

questions.text:
Match the neurological disorders in Column A with their characteristic EEG findings in Column B.

 

Column A (Neurological Disorder)

 

  1. West syndrome
  2. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) 
  3. Absence seizures
  4. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
  5. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

 

Column B (EEG Feature)

 

  1. 4-5 Hz spike
  2. Periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes
  3. 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
  4. Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)
  5. 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves with polyspike bursts in sleep
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A, 5-E

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • EEG findings are essential for diagnosing epilepsy syndromes and neurodegenerative diseases.
  • West syndrome shows hypsarrhythmia, while absence seizures are characterized by 3 Hz spike-wave patterns.
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease presents with periodic sharp waves, differentiating it from other encephalopathies.
  • Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome have distinct EEG patterns critical for diagnosis and treatment planning.

choices.text: Inadequate eyelid closure due to orbicularis weakness
Partial obstruction of distal nasolacrimal duct
Primary hypersecretion due to reflex tearing

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with complaints of excessive tearing from her right eye. She denies pain, discharge, or recent trauma. An ophthalmic evaluation is performed, and both Jones Test I and Jones Test II are negative. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inadequate eyelid closure due to orbicularis weakness

 

Negative Jones Test I and II suggest that fluorescein dye instilled into the conjunctival sac fails to appear in the nose (Test I), and flushing the system retrograde with saline (Test II) also fails to retrieve the dye. This combination points to lacrimal pump failure, which prevents proper drainage of tears despite an intact canalicular system particularly.

 

  • Jones Test I evaluates passive drainage.
  • Jones Test II helps distinguish between anatomical obstruction and lacrimal pump dysfunction.
  • If both Jones Tests are negative, it can imply lacrimal pump failure.
  • “In case of total mechanical obstruction, the syringing test will be negative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Partial obstruction of distal nasolacrimal duct: This would typically still allow some dye retrieval with irrigation during Jones Test II. A negative result for both tests suggests more than just a partial anatomical block. Additionally, the document edits indicate a preference for interpreting this as pump failure, not partial obstruction.

 

Option C. Complete obstruction of lacrimal canaliculi: This would cause both tests to be negative, but it typically presents with reflux during irrigation and often with pain or discharge due to stagnation or infection. The patient denies pain and discharge, and the notes favor a diagnosis of pump failure over total obstruction.

 

Option D. Primary hypersecretion due to reflex tearing: This would not cause both Jones Tests to be negative, because the lacrimal drainage system remains intact. Reflex tearing usually follows ocular irritation, which is absent here—there is no trauma, pain, or discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with epiphora and both Jones Tests negative, lacrimal pump failure due to orbicularis oculi weakness must be considered as a functional cause of impaired tear drainage, even in the absence of anatomical obstruction.

questions.text:
Match the Aortic Arch in Column A with their corresponding developmental derivatives in Column B: 

 

Column A (Aortic Arch)

 

  1. 1st Aortic Arch
  2. 2nd Aortic Arch
  3. 3rd Aortic Arch
  4. 4th Aortic Arch
  5. 5th Aortic Arch
  6. 6th Aortic Arch

 

Column B (Developmental Derivative)

 

  1. Left: Arch of aorta between left common carotid and left subclavian; Right: Right subclavian artery
  2. Maxillary artery
  3. Hyoid artery 
  4. Common carotid artery, Proximal part of internal carotid and external carotid artery
  5. Proximal part: Pulmonary artery; Distal part: Ductus arteriosus on left, disappears on right
  6. Disappear completely
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A, 5-F, 6-E

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in for evaluation after the parents noticed an apparent eye misalignment in recent photographs. The child has had normal development, with no concerns during pregnancy or delivery. On physical examination, the corneal light reflex is symmetric, and no true misalignment is observed. However, the child has a broad nasal bridge and prominent epicanthal folds. All other ophthalmologic findings are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostrabismus

 

  • Pseudostrabismus refers to the false impression of ocular misalignment, commonly seen in infants and young children with broad nasal bridges or prominent epicanthal folds. 
  • These features create an illusion of esotropia (inward deviation), especially in photographs. The key diagnostic clue is a normal corneal light reflex, confirming that the eyes are properly aligned.

 

 

In this clinical scenario:

 

  • The child is developmentally normal.
  • There is no true misalignment, as indicated by a normal Hirschberg (corneal light reflex) test.
  • Prominent epicanthal folds support the diagnosis.


Other Options: 

 

Option A. Convergence spasm: This is a rare condition usually seen in older children or adults involving simultaneous involuntary convergence, miosis, and accommodation, often functional in origin and not associated with epicanthal folds.

 

Option B. Accommodative squint: This refers to a true strabismus often associated with uncorrected hyperopia, presenting as esotropia. Unlike pseudostrabismus, it results in a displaced corneal light reflex and often responds to corrective lenses.

 

Option D. Latent nystagmus: A subtle involuntary eye movement that becomes apparent under monocular viewing conditions. It does not mimic squint, and the corneal light reflex is typically unaffected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudostrabismus is a benign condition in young children caused by facial features like epicanthal folds or a flat nasal bridge, creating a false impression of eye deviation. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a symmetric corneal light reflex and absence of true ocular misalignment.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding different patterns of vitiligo are true?

 

  1. Segmental vitiligo commonly involves the trigeminal nerve distribution and is associated with autoimmune diseases.
  2. Vitiligo vulgaris is the most common type and shows widespread distribution with possible family history.
  3. Acrofacial vitiligo involves the lips, penis, and nipple, and shows excellent response to treatment due to rich hair density.
  4. Segmental vitiligo often shows leukotrichia and has a relatively stable clinical course.
  5. Vitiligo universalis is typically localized to the periorbital and perioral areas.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 2 – True: Vitiligo vulgaris is the most common type and typically presents with widespread depigmentation and often has a positive family history.

 

Statement 4 – True: Segmental vitiligo shows leukotrichia and a stable course after initial progression.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1 – False: Segmental vitiligo commonly involves the trigeminal distribution and occurs in children, but it is not associated with autoimmune diseases.

 

Statement 3 – False: The areas described (lips, penis, nipple) are involved in lip-tip vitiligo, not acrofacial vitiligo. Also, these regions lack hair, making them resistant to treatment.

 

Statement 5 – False: Vitiligo universalis involves widespread depigmentation (almost complete) and is often associated with multiple endocrinopathies, not just localized involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitiligo presents in various patterns, with vitiligo vulgaris being the most common. Segmental vitiligo occurs in children, is not autoimmune-associated, and shows leukotrichia with poor treatment response.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with progressive lower limb weakness and numbness following a diarrheal illness two weeks ago. Examination shows hypotonia, areflexia, and bilateral flaccid paralysis in the legs. Sensation is preserved. Past medical records indicate that she has been suffering from selective IgA deficiency. What is the best initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasma Exchange

 

This patient likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) following a diarrheal illness. IVIG is contraindicated in IgA deficiency due to risk of anaphylaxis. Hence, plasma exchange becomes the preferred first-line treatment in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-dose corticosteroids: Not effective in GBS; not recommended as monotherapy.

 

Option B. IVIG: Contraindicated in known IgA deficiency due to risk of hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. Rituximab: Not used in GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma exchange is the treatment of choice for GBS in patients with IgA deficiency, where IVIG is contraindicated.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory investigations would most accurately confirm the diagnosis of rotavirus diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

  • Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe watery diarrhea in infants and young children, especially in those who are unvaccinated.
  • The most accurate and commonly used diagnostic method is detection of rotavirus antigen in stool.
  • This is done via enzyme immunoassay (EIA) or latex agglutination, providing rapid and sensitive results.
  • The test directly identifies viral particles in the gastrointestinal tract, confirming active infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antigen detection in blood: Not a method used for rotavirus diagnosis. The virus primarily infects intestinal epithelium; antigen is not reliably present in the blood.

 

Option B. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is useful for identifying parasites or ova, but not effective for detecting rotavirus, which requires more sensitive, virus-specific assays.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: Can indicate past exposure or vaccine response, but is not suitable for diagnosing acute rotavirus infection, as it doesn’t reflect current viral shedding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of rotavirus diarrhea is best confirmed by detecting rotavirus antigen in stool samples using enzyme immunoassay or latex agglutination techniques.

questions.text:
A microbiology lab is reviewing culture and staining characteristics to confirm a suspected case of pertussis. Which of the following statements regarding Bordetella pertussis is incorrect? 

 

  1. The most appropriate specimen for isolation is a nasopharyngeal aspirate.
  2. Regan-Lowe medium and Bordet-Gengou agar are used for culturing the organism.
  3. The colonies typically exhibit a metallic sheen with black center on eosin methylene blue agar.
  4. On culture, colonies may resemble mercury drops or bisected pearls.
  5. Gram-stained smears may show coccobacilli in a thumbprint arrangement.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 3

 

3. The colonies typically exhibit a metallic sheen with black center on eosin methylene blue agar: Incorrect, the description of metallic sheen with black center is characteristic of E. coli on eosin methylene blue (EMB) agar, not Bordetella pertussis. B. pertussis does not grow on EMB agar and instead requires specialized media such as Bordet-Gengou or Regan-Lowe medium. Thus, this statement is false and is the correct answer to the question.

 

Correct Statements:

 

1. The most appropriate specimen for isolation is a nasopharyngeal aspirate: Correct, A nasopharyngeal aspirate is considered the most effective specimen for isolating B. pertussis, as it resides in the ciliated respiratory epithelium.

 

2. Regan-Lowe medium and Bordet-Gengou agar are used for culturing the organism: Correct, B. pertussis is cultured using special enriched media, most notably Bordet-Gengou glycerine-potato-blood agar and Regan-Lowe charcoal medium, which support the growth of this fastidious organism.

 

4. On culture, colonies may resemble mercury drops or bisected pearls: Correct, B. pertussis colonies have a characteristic appearance, often described as mercury drop or bisected pearls, which helps in visual identification on culture.

 

5. Gram-stained smears may show coccobacilli in a thumbprint arrangement: Correct, on direct smear from culture or clinical sample, B. pertussis appears as coccobacilli arranged in a "thumbprint" pattern, which is a classic morphological clue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bordetella pertussis does not grow on eosin methylene blue (EMB) agar; it requires special media such as Bordet-Gengou or Regan-Lowe. Colonies show mercury drop appearance, and the organism appears as coccobacilli in a thumbprint pattern on smear.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding seminoma are true? 

 

1. Histology reveals large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, resembling spermatogonia
2. Seminoma is the most common testicular tumor and resembles ovarian dysgerminoma
3. It commonly presents with hemorrhage and necrosis within the testicular mass
4. It is radiosensitive and associated with an excellent prognosis
5. β-hCG is always elevated and required for diagnosis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4

 

1. Histology reveals large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, resembling spermatogonia: Correct, this description is classic for seminoma and is directly quoted from the source material. The cells resemble spermatogonia, and the tumor is composed of large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei.

 

 

2. Seminoma is the most common testicular tumor and resembles ovarian dysgerminoma: Correct, Seminoma is the most common testicular germ cell tumor and has a histologic counterpart in females called dysgerminoma, found in the ovary.

 

4. It is radiosensitive and associated with an excellent prognosis: Correct, Seminoma is highly sensitive to radiotherapy, and patients typically have a very good prognosis.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

3. It commonly presents with hemorrhage and necrosis within the testicular mass: Incorrect, this is a key differentiating feature. Seminoma forms a homogeneous, solid mass and is not associated with hemorrhage or necrosis. These features are more typical of embryonal carcinoma, another type of testicular germ cell tumor.

 

5. β-hCG is always elevated and required for diagnosis: Incorrect, although rare cases of seminoma may produce β-hCG, it is not a consistent finding and is not required for diagnosis. Many seminomas are β-hCG negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminoma is the most common testicular tumor, composed of large clear cells with central nuclei. It forms a homogeneous mass without hemorrhage or necrosis, resembles ovarian dysgerminoma, is radiosensitive, and has an excellent prognosis. β-hCG may be elevated in rare cases.

choices.text: Yes, because he has no macrovascular invasion or extrahepatic disease.
No, because he exceeds the tumor size criteria.
No, as the Milan criteria are not applicable if more than 2 tumours are present on imaging.
No, because the Milan criteria only allow a single tumor ≤5 cm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis B is being evaluated for liver transplantation due to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Imaging reveals three tumors measuring 2.5 cm, 3.0 cm, and 3.2 cm, with no evidence of extrahepatic spread or vascular invasion. According to the Milan Criteria, is this patient eligible for liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) No, because he exceeds the tumor size criteria.
 

Milan Criteria for Liver Transplantation in HCC:

 

  • Single tumor ≤ 5 cm OR
  • Up to 3 tumors, each ≤ 3 cm
  • No extrahepatic involvement
  • No macrovascular invasion


Why is this patient ineligible?

 

  • He has three tumors, but one of them is 3.2 cm, which exceeds the 3 cm limit.
  • Even though he has no extrahepatic spread or vascular invasion, he does not meet Milan criteria due to tumor size.


Other Options:
 

Option A. Yes, because he has no macrovascular invasion or extrahepatic disease: Incorrect, while absence of vascular invasion and extrahepatic spread is necessary, tumor size also matters.
 

Option C. No, as the Milan criteria are not applicable if more than 2 tumours are present on imaging: Incorrect, Milan criteria is applicable upto 3 tumours.
 

Option D. No, because the Milan criteria only allow a single tumor ≤5 cm: Incorrect: Milan criteria allow up to 3 tumors, but with a size restriction of ≤3 cm each.


Educational Objective:
 

  • Milan Criteria is the gold standard for selecting HCC patients for liver transplantation.
  • It ensures optimal survival outcomes while minimizing recurrence risk.
  • Patients exceeding Milan Criteria may be considered under expanded criteria (e.g., UCSF criteria) or down-staged before listing.

choices.text: The sense strand of DNA is the strand used by RNA polymerase during transcription.
The antisense DNA strand is identical to the RNA transcript except that the DNA strand contains thymine and the RNA strand contains uracil.
The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences.
Mature mRNA contains a cap at the 5′-end, a poly(A) tail at the 3′ end, introns, and exons.

questions.text: The production of mRNA in eukaryotic cells requires a large number of steps, and drugs targeted to any of these steps could block mRNA production. Which one of the following accurately describes a part of the process of producing mRNA from a eukaryotic gene?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences.

 

  • The first RNA form produced by RNA polymerase is hnRNA, which contains both intron (noncoding) and exon (coding sequences) sequences. hnRNA is modified by the addition of a cap to the 5′-end, a poly(A) tail added to the 3′-end, and all introns removed. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The sense (or coding) strand of DNA: The sense (or coding) strand of DNA is identical to the mRNA produced, with the exception of the DNA containing thymine and the RNA containing uracil. 


Option B. The template (or antisense) strand of DNA: The template (or antisense) strand of DNA is the strand that is used by RNA polymerase to produce a complementary RNA sequence to the template strand (thus, the antisense strand is complementary to the mRNA produced and is not identical to it). 


Option D. During processing: The intron sequences are removed from the hnRNA to produce the mature mRNA.


Educational Objective:


The initial RNA transcript (hnRNA) in eukaryotic cells contains both introns and exons and must undergo splicing and other modifications before becoming mature mRNA.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and unintentional weight loss over 3 months. Examination reveals digital clubbing and decreased breath sounds on the right. Chest X-ray shows a right hilar mass. CT-guided biopsy confirms small cell lung carcinoma. Lab results reveal serum sodium of 122 mmol/L and urine sodium of 60 mmol/L with high urine osmolality. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluid restriction

 

  • The patient likely has SIADH secondary to small cell lung carcinoma. 
  • Hyponatremia with inappropriately concentrated urine and elevated urine sodium confirms the diagnosis. 
  • Fluid restriction is the first-line therapy in asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic SIADH.

 

Other Options:


Option A. IV 3% saline: Reserved for severe or symptomatic hyponatremia with seizures or coma.

 

Option C. Oral salt tablets: Can be used adjunctively but not as initial monotherapy.

 

Option D. Vasopressin receptor antagonist: Reserved for refractory cases or when fluid restriction fails.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid restriction is the first-line treatment for SIADH-induced hyponatremia in the setting of small cell lung carcinoma.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman recently completed a 10-day course of clindamycin for cellulitis. Two weeks later, she presents with watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fever. Stool testing is positive for Clostridioides difficile toxin B gene. She is diagnosed with non-severe initial CDI and has no history of prior infections. Which of the following medications should be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fidaxomicin

 

Fidaxomicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic indicated for the treatment of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). It works by inhibiting the sigma subunit of bacterial RNA polymerase, thereby suppressing transcription and protein synthesis. Because it is minimally absorbed from the GI tract, it acts locally in the colon, which is ideal for CDI.

 

Key advantages:

 

  • Narrow-spectrum activity targeting C. difficile
  • Minimal disruption to normal gut flora
  • Lower recurrence rates compared to vancomycin

 

Fidaxomicin is now recommended as a first-line treatment for non-severe or recurrent CDI, especially in high-risk patients.


Other Options: 

 

Option A. Azithromycin: A macrolide antibiotic used to treat respiratory infections, chlamydia, and others. It does not inhibit RNA polymerase and is not used in CDI.

 

Option C. Vancomycin (oral): Effective in CDI and inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis. However, unlike fidaxomicin, it is not as effective at preventing recurrences.

 

Option D. Rifaximin: Minimally absorbed antibiotic used primarily for hepatic encephalopathy and traveler’s diarrhea. Sometimes used as adjunct therapy after vancomycin in CDI relapse, but not first-line for initial infection.


Educational Objective:

 

Fidaxomicin is a first-line oral antibiotic for Clostridioides difficile infection. It acts by inhibiting the sigma subunit of RNA polymerase and is associated with lower recurrence rates compared to vancomycin.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with 3-day history of gross hematuria. He reports no fever, rash, or history of recent infections. Vital signs are stable, but his laboratory tests show a blood urea nitrogen of 39 mg/dL and creatinine of 4.1 mg/dL. A renal biopsy is performed, and immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-IgG shows a linear pattern along the glomerular basement membrane (shown in the image below). Which of the following serologic findings is most likely to be detected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibody

 

  • This patient presents with acute kidney injury, hematuria, and an immunofluorescence pattern that reveals linear IgG staining along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) — a classic finding in anti-GBM disease (also known as Goodpasture syndrome when lung involvement is present).
  • The linear pattern indicates direct binding of antibodies to the GBM, not immune complex deposition.
  • The disease is characterized by the presence of anti–GBM antibodies in serum, which target type IV collagen in the basement membrane.
  • These autoantibodies trigger a Type II hypersensitivity reaction, leading to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) and acute renal failure.

 

Every phrase from the image description and text (e.g., "linear pattern," "anti–IgG," "renal biopsy," "creatinine elevation") points specifically to anti–GBM disease.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis B surface antigen: Hepatitis B is associated with membranous nephropathy and polyarteritis nodosa, but these conditions do not present with linear IgG staining. There is no mention of viral history or antigenemia in this case.

 

Option C. Circulating immune complexes against C1q: This points toward immune complex–mediated glomerulonephritis, such as lupus nephritis, which shows a granular ("lumpy-bumpy") pattern on immunofluorescence — not the linear pattern seen here.

 

Option D. Anti–streptolysin O antibody: ASO antibodies are associated with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which also shows a granular immune complex deposition pattern (not linear) and usually occurs 1–3 weeks after pharyngitis or skin infection, which is absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A linear pattern of IgG staining along the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence is diagnostic for anti–GBM disease. This autoimmune condition is confirmed by detecting anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies in the serum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. Drug susceptibility testing reveals resistance to isoniazid, rifampicin, and one of the levofloxacin. He has no prior history of tuberculosis treatment. Which of the following best describes this resistance pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pre-extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (Pre-XDR-TB)

 

According to WHO definitions, tuberculosis (TB) drug resistance classifications are based on specific patterns of resistance:

 

  • Multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB): Resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most powerful first-line TB drugs.
  • Pre-extensively drug-resistant TB (Pre-XDR-TB): MDR-TB plus resistance to any fluoroquinolone (e.g., levofloxacin, moxifloxacin).
  • Extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB): Pre-XDR-TB plus resistance to at least one Group A drug, such as bedaquiline or linezolid.

 

In this case, the patient has no prior TB treatment (which is relevant but does not alter resistance classification), and testing shows resistance to isoniazid, rifampicin, and a fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin). This fits the Pre-XDR-TB definition precisely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB): MDR-TB is defined as resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin only, without additional fluoroquinolone resistance. This patient has additional resistance to levofloxacin, so this definition is incomplete.

 

Option C. Extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB): XDR-TB requires resistance to isoniazid, rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and a Group A drug (e.g., bedaquiline or linezolid). Since no resistance to Group A drugs is mentioned, this is not XDR-TB.

 

Option D. Drug-sensitive tuberculosis: This refers to no resistance to first-line or second-line TB drugs. Clearly incorrect, as the patient has resistance to three important drugs.


Educational Objective:

 

Pre-extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (Pre-XDR-TB) is defined as TB resistant to isoniazid, rifampicin, and any fluoroquinolone (e.g., levofloxacin), and must be recognized for appropriate treatment planning.

questions.text:
Match the conditions in Column A with their most commonly associated pathogens in Column B. 

 

Column A (Conditions)

 

  1. Acute epiglottitis
  2. Furunculosis
  3. Otomycosis
  4. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis

 

Column B (Pathogens)

 

  1. Aspergillus niger
  2. Staphylococcus aureus
  3. Aspergillus fumigatus
  4. Haemophilus influenzae
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-4, B-2, C-1, D-3

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haemophilus influenzae is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis.
  • Staphylococcus aureus frequently causes furunculosis (boil formation).
  • Aspergillus niger is a major cause of otomycosis (fungal ear infection).
  • Aspergillus fumigatus is commonly associated with allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

choices.text: Lack of randomization in individual studies.
An increased likelihood of publication bias.
Overestimation of the intervention’s effect size.

questions.text: In a systematic review assessing the effectiveness of a novel antidepressant, researchers utilize a funnel plot to evaluate the integrity of the data compiled from various studies. Upon analysis, they observe notable asymmetry in the funnel plot. Considering this finding, a clinical researcher is concerned about the biases affecting the results. What does the observed asymmetry in the funnel plot most likely indicate about the studies included in the meta-analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) An increased likelihood of publication bias.

 

  • Funnel plot asymmetry is a diagnostic tool used to suggest the presence of publication bias in a meta-analysis. 
  • Asymmetry in a funnel plot often indicates that smaller studies showing no effect or negative effects might not be published as frequently as those showing significant effects, skewing the overall analysis towards more positive outcomes. 
  • This can critically impact the meta-analysis's conclusions, suggesting a bias in the literature available.

 

Other Options:

Option A. Lack of randomization in individual studies: Lack of randomization is a different issue that affects study quality and bias within individual studies, not directly detected by funnel plots.


Option C. Overestimation of the intervention’s effect size: Overestimation of the effect size is a potential consequence of publication bias but not the direct indication of funnel plot asymmetry itself.


Option D. Underrepresentation of smaller studies: Underrepresentation of smaller studies is indeed a symptom of publication bias, but option B more comprehensively describes the core issue indicated by funnel plot asymmetry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify funnel plot asymmetry as a sign of publication bias in meta-analyses, indicating a potential exclusion of smaller or negative studies that skews results toward positive outcomes. 
  • Recognize the importance of strategies to mitigate this bias for accurate conclusions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) and intermenstrual spotting for the past 6 months. She has no history of pelvic inflammatory disease or recent infections. A transvaginal ultrasound is inconclusive, so the physician performs a hysterosalpingography (HSG) to evaluate the uterine cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometrial Polyp

 

  • Endometrial polyps appear as well-defined, smooth, intracavitary filling defects on HSG.
  • They may be pedunculated or sessile and outlined by contrast within the uterine cavity.
  • Common symptoms include AUB, intermenstrual spotting, and infertility.
  • Best diagnosed with sonohysterography or hysteroscopy.

 

Other Options: 
 

Option B. Genital Tuberculosis: HSG findings in genital TB typically show multiple irregular filling defects, intrauterine adhesions, or beaded fallopian tubes. Patients usually have a history of chronic pelvic pain and infertility.


Option C. Intra mural fibroid uterus: Fibroids (submucosal) appear as broad-based, irregular filling defects, often distorting the uterine contour. Fibroids are more heterogeneous on imaging than polyps.


Option D. Asherman Syndrome:  Characterized by intrauterine adhesions, leading to a shrunken or obliterated cavity on HSG. Patients often present with secondary amenorrhea and infertility following prior uterine instrumentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endometrial polyps are common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding and appear as smooth, intracavitary filling defects on HSG.
  • Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosis and treatment.
  • Differentiate from submucosal fibroids (irregular filling defects) and Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the contributions of these historical figures to medicine?

 

  1. Andreas Vesalius authored "De Humani Corporis Fabrica" and advanced anatomical science with detailed human dissections.
  2. Samuel Hahnemann founded the practice of Naturopathy.
  3. Avicenna wrote "The Canon of Medicine," which was used as a standard medical text in the Islamic world and Europe.
  4. Charaka is known as the father of Western medicine.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3


Correct Statement 1: Andreas Vesalius is indeed credited with authoring "De Humani Corporis Fabrica," a seminal work in the history of anatomy that laid the foundation for modern anatomical science through detailed dissections and illustrations. This text marked a significant shift from the reliance on classical sources to empirical observation.

 

Correct Statement 3: Avicenna’s "The Canon of Medicine" was a comprehensive medical text that synthesized the medical knowledge of the ancient Greeks and Islamic scholars. It was highly influential across both the Islamic world and Europe for several centuries, serving as a standard textbook in many medieval universities.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2: Samuel Hahnemann is the founder of Homeopathy, not Naturopathy. Homeopathy is based on the principle of "like cures like" and uses highly diluted substances to treat symptoms.

 

Statement 4: Charaka is known as one of the principal contributors to Ayurveda, not Western medicine. He is often referred to as the father of Indian medicine, and his works are fundamental to understanding Ayurvedic principles.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Start antitubercular therapy first, then ART after 2 weeks
Start both ART and ATT on day one

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with known HIV presents with 3 weeks of cough, fever, and weight loss. He has discontinued his ART 2 years ago. Chest X-ray shows bilateral upper lobe cavitary lesions and sputum is positive for acid-fast bacilli. His CD4 count is 180 cells/mm³. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start antitubercular therapy first, then ART after 2 weeks

 

Starting ART immediately in active TB can lead to immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). With CD4 >100 and no CNS involvement, delaying ART by 2 weeks after ATT initiation is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start antiretroviral therapy immediately:  Increases risk of IRIS when TB is active.
