questions.text: A 72-year-old woman, a known case of Alzheimer’s disease, presents with involuntary urine leakage, especially when she is unable to reach the bathroom in time. She reports frequent urgency to urinate but passes only small amounts each time. An anticholinergic medication is prescribed to improve bladder control that does not cross the blood-brain barrier, thereby minimizing central nervous system side effects. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trospium

 

This elderly patient with Alzheimer’s disease is experiencing urge incontinence, characterized by involuntary urine leakage due to detrusor overactivity. Anticholinergic drugs are commonly used to improve bladder control by inhibiting muscarinic receptors in the bladder, thereby relaxing the detrusor muscle and increasing bladder capacity.

 

However, in patients with Alzheimer’s disease, medications that cross the blood-brain barrier and exert central anticholinergic effects can worsen cognitive function. Therefore, Trospium is the preferred agent in this case because:

 

  • It is an antimuscarinic drug used to treat overactive bladder.
  • It is hydrophilic and positively charged, which prevents it from crossing the blood-brain barrier.
  • It provides bladder control while minimizing central nervous system side effects—a key consideration in patients with neurodegenerative conditions like Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Oxybutynin: While effective for urge incontinence, oxybutynin is lipophilic and crosses the blood-brain barrier, leading to CNS side effects such as confusion, memory loss, and worsening of dementia. Thus, it is not ideal for elderly patients with Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Option B. Mirabegron: This is a beta-3 adrenergic agonist, not an anticholinergic. Although it does not cause CNS anticholinergic effects, it acts via a different mechanism and was not described in the question, which specifies an anticholinergic medication.

 

Option D. Tolterodine: Tolterodine is an antimuscarinic agent, but it is lipophilic and can cross the blood-brain barrier, potentially causing central side effects, including worsening of cognition in patients with Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trospium is an anticholinergic drug used for overactive bladder that does not cross the blood-brain barrier, making it suitable for elderly patients or those with Alzheimer’s disease to avoid central nervous system side effects.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips, and hepatosplenomegaly. He also has copious nasal discharge and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. On examination, the child has joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hurler Disease (Mucopolysaccharidosis Type I)

 

  • Hurler Syndrome (MPS I) is caused by a deficiency of L-iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), resulting in progressive multi-system involvement.
  • Clinical features include: 
    • Coarse facial features (gargoyle-like facies)
    • Macroglossia (large tongue) and thick lips
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Corneal clouding
    • Prominent forehead and skeletal dysplasia (dysostosis multiplex)
    • Joint stiffness and short stature
    • Recurrent respiratory infections and copious nasal discharge
    • Cardiac complications (valvular heart disease, obstructive airway disease)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS): incorrect.

 

  • BWS presents with macroglossia, organomegaly, neonatal hypoglycemia, and an increased risk of childhood tumors (Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma).
  • No coarse facial features, skeletal dysplasia, or joint stiffness.

 

Option C. Proteus Syndrome: incorrect.

 

  • A rare overgrowth disorder with asymmetrical gigantism, lipomas, skeletal anomalies, and vascular malformations.
  • Does not cause coarse facial features or mucopolysaccharidosis-like symptoms.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: incorrect.

 

  • Congenital hypothyroidism can cause macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and developmental delay, but does not cause hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal dysplasia, or coarse facies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hurler syndrome (MPS I) presents with coarse facies, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal dysplasia, and recurrent respiratory infections.
  • Caused by L-iduronidase deficiency, leading to glycosaminoglycan (GAG) accumulation.
  • Diagnosis confirmed by enzyme assay and genetic testing.
  • Bone marrow transplantation and enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) are the mainstay treatments.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of moderate persistent asthma presents to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea and chest tightness over the past 12 hours. She has already taken multiple doses of inhaled salbutamol without relief. On examination, she is speaking in short phrases, has marked use of accessory muscles, and a silent chest on auscultation. Arterial blood gas reveals pH 7.21, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and PaO₂ 64 mmHg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation

 

The patient is in near-respiratory arrest with signs of impending failure: silent chest, hypercapnia (PaCO₂ 58), and acidemia (pH 7.21). These findings indicate ventilatory failure. Immediate intubation is warranted to secure the airway and provide controlled ventilation before complete collapse occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV MgSO₄: Used in severe asthma but not sufficient in ventilatory failure.

 

Option B. Start non-invasive ventilation: Contraindicated in asthma exacerbation due to risk of air trapping and ineffective ventilation.

 

Option D. Give nebulized ipratropium: Adjunct therapy but not adequate in this life-threatening stage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a patient with severe asthma and evidence of ventilatory failure, immediate endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are lifesaving and should not be delayed.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause a drug interaction by inhibiting cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to increased plasma concentrations of co-administered drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketoconazole

 

Ketoconazole is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP3A4. By inhibiting these enzymes, ketoconazole can reduce the metabolism of many other drugs, leading to increased plasma levels, prolonged drug action, and enhanced risk of toxicity. This is a classic cause of pharmacokinetic drug interactions.


Other Options:



(All CYP450 Inducers):

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: A CYP450 inducer, not an inhibitor. It increases the metabolism of other drugs, possibly reducing their efficacy.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: Also a strong enzyme inducer, especially of CYP3A4. It enhances the breakdown of other drugs.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: Another CYP450 inducer, commonly affecting drugs metabolized by CYP2C and CYP3A subfamilies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketoconazole is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP3A4, and can increase the plasma concentration of co-administered drugs by reducing their metabolism.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man who recently returned from sub-Saharan Africa presents with hematuria and dysuria. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria and the presence of eggs with a terminal spine on microscopy. Which of the following parasitic infections is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schistosoma haematobium

 

  • Schistosoma haematobium is a trematode (fluke) associated with urinary tract infections.
  • It is endemic in Africa and the Middle East and typically causes urinary schistosomiasis, presenting with hematuria, dysuria, and, in chronic cases, bladder wall fibrosis or even squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
  • Its characteristic egg has a terminal spine, which helps differentiate it from other schistosome species.
  • Eggs are typically found in the urine, not stool.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schistosoma mansoni: This species is associated with intestinal schistosomiasis and hepatosplenic disease. Its eggs have a lateral spine, not terminal. Eggs are found in stool, not urine.

 

Option B. Clonorchis sinensis: A liver fluke that causes biliary tract infections and is associated with cholangiocarcinoma. Eggs are small, operculated, and do not have terminal or lateral spines.

 

Option D. Schistosoma japonicum: Also causes intestinal schistosomiasis and is associated with hepatic complications. The eggs are round with a small lateral spine that is often inconspicuous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schistosoma haematobium is the only schistosome species with terminal-spined eggs and is classically associated with urinary tract involvement, including hematuria and bladder pathology.

choices.text: Solution X: 1 M CaCl₂ | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: 1 M glucose
Solution X: 1 M glucose | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: 1 M CaCl₂
Solution X: 1 M NaCl | Solution Y: 2 M glucose | Solution Z: 3 M CaCl₂
Solution X: 2 M NaCl | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: Pure water

questions.text: In the experiment illustrated in part A of Figure 2, equal volumes of solutions X, Y, and Z are placed into the compartments of the two U-shaped vessels shown. The two compartments of each vessel are separated by semipermeable membranes (i.e., impermeable to ions and large polar molecules). Part B illustrates the fluid distribution across the membranes at equilibration. Assuming complete dissociation, identify each of the solutions shown.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Solution X: 1 M glucose | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: 1 M CaCl₂

 

  1. Concept of Osmolarity and Osmosis:
    • The movement of water occurs from a region of lower osmolarity to a region of higher osmolarity across a semipermeable membrane.
    • The degree of dissociation of solutes affects the total osmolarity of each solution.
    • Complete dissociation occurs for ionic solutes like NaCl and CaCl₂, while glucose remains undissociated.
  2. Dissociation and Osmolarity Calculation:
    • 1 M glucose → 1 Osm/L (glucose does not dissociate)
    • 1 M NaCl → 2 Osm/L (NaCl dissociates into Na⁺ and Cl⁻)
    • 1 M CaCl₂ → 3 Osm/L (CaCl₂ dissociates into Ca²⁺ and 2 Cl⁻)
  3. Understanding Figure 2:
    • Initial placement in Part A:
      • X (1 M glucose), Y (1 M NaCl), Z (1 M CaCl₂)
    • At Equilibrium in Part B:
      • Water moves towards higher osmolarity solutions to equalize the osmotic pressure.
      • Z (1 M CaCl₂) has the highest osmolarity (3 Osm/L), drawing the most water into its compartment.
      • Y (1 M NaCl, 2 Osm/L) gains water relative to X (1 M glucose, 1 Osm/L), making its fluid level higher than X but lower than Z.
      • X (1 M glucose) has the lowest osmolarity (1 Osm/L) and loses water to Y and Z.
  4. Fluid Level Changes at Equilibration:
    • Z (CaCl₂) has the highest fluid level.
    • Y (NaCl) has a moderately high fluid level.
    • X (glucose) has the lowest fluid level.

 

This pattern matches (1 M glucose, 1 M NaCl, 1 M CaCl₂) as the correct identification of solutions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The movement of water across semipermeable membranes follows osmotic gradients. Ionic solutes like NaCl and CaCl₂ dissociate completely, increasing osmolarity and pulling water into their compartments. 
  • Non-dissociating solutes like glucose have lower osmolarity and lose water in osmotic equilibrium. Understanding these principles is essential in clinical settings such as IV fluid administration and electrolyte management.

choices.text: Metabolism to lactate via anaerobic glycolysis

questions.text: Following a carbohydrate-rich meal, a patient’s liver converts excess glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. Under fed-state conditions, what is the primary fate of this metabolite in hepatocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Storage as glycogen

 

  • In the fed state, high insulin levels promote glycogenesis, the process of converting glucose-6-phosphate into glycogen for storage, particularly in liver and muscle.
  • In the liver, glucose uptake occurs via insulin-independent GLUT2 transporters, and insulin activates glycogen synthase through dephosphorylation.
  • The conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glycogen is the primary pathway utilized by hepatocytes to manage excess glucose after a meal.
  • This is a critical storage mechanism, preventing postprandial hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion into ketone bodies: Ketogenesis primarily occurs in the fasted state or during prolonged starvation, when insulin is low and fatty acid oxidation is high. It is not active in the fed state and is not a fate of glucose-6-phosphate.

 

Option B. Oxidation via β-oxidation: β-oxidation is the process of breaking down fatty acids, not glucose-6-phosphate. This pathway is suppressed in the fed state due to high insulin levels, which inhibit lipolysis.

 

Option D. Metabolism to lactate via anaerobic glycolysis: Anaerobic glycolysis, and hence lactate production, is prominent in tissues with low oxygen (e.g., exercising muscle, RBCs). In the liver during the fed state, glycolysis is aerobic, and glucose-6-phosphate is not primarily diverted to lactate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the fed state, the primary fate of glucose-6-phosphate in the liver is conversion to glycogen, driven by elevated insulin promoting glycogenesis.

choices.text: Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis
Hypermetabolic state after death due to thyrotoxicosis
Early onset of rigor mortis caused by thyrotoxicosis, preventing cooling

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of thyrotoxicosis is found dead in his home. The body temperature is 39°C measured 6 hours post-mortem, while the room temperature is 21°C. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the elevated body temperature after death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis

 

  • In this case, the elevated post-mortem body temperature (39°C) compared to the room temperature (21°C) suggests delayed cooling of the body. 
  • The most plausible explanation is that the individual was in a hypermetabolic state prior to death, due to thyrotoxicosis, leading to increased heat production.

 

Thyrotoxicosis is known to cause:

 

  • Increased basal metabolic rate
  • Excessive heat generation
  • Elevated core body temperature prior to death

 

Once death occurs, metabolic processes cease, and no further heat is produced. Therefore, (hypermetabolic state after death) is physiologically incorrect—there is no metabolism after death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypermetabolic state after death due to thyrotoxicosis: Incorrect, after death, the body’s metabolic activity stops entirely. There can be no hypermetabolic state post-mortem, regardless of pre-existing conditions.

 

Option C. Early onset of rigor mortis caused by thyrotoxicosis, preventing cooling:  While thyrotoxicosis may accelerate rigor mortis, rigor mortis does not prevent heat loss. Cooling of the body (algor mortis) is primarily influenced by environmental factors and body mass, not rigor mortis.

 

Option D. Both A and C:  Incorrect, Only Option A is valid. Option C is not a valid explanation for the elevated temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-mortem elevation of body temperature can result from pre-death hypermetabolic states such as thyrotoxicosis; metabolism ceases after death, and rigor mortis does not prevent heat loss.

questions.text: A 24-year-old elite basketball player complains of progressive anterior knee pain for the past 3 months. The pain worsens with jumping, sprinting, or climbing stairs. On examination, tenderness is elicited precisely at the inferior pole of the patella, and resisted knee extension aggravates the pain. MRI is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jumper’s knee

 

  • Jumper’s knee (also known as patellar tendinopathy) is a chronic overuse injury that commonly affects athletes, especially those involved in jumping sports like basketball or volleyball.
  • The pain is located at the inferior pole of the patella, where the patellar tendon attaches.
  • The condition is typically due to repetitive strain on the patellar tendon, leading to microscopic tears and inflammation.
  • MRI findings would often show thickening of the patellar tendon, tendinosis, and sometimes degeneration in the tendon without complete rupture.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Patellar Tendon Rupture:

 

  • Patellar tendon rupture is an acute injury that usually occurs after a traumatic event (e.g., fall, jump).
  • The patient would experience severe pain, inability to extend the knee, and a palpable gap in the tendon, along with loss of knee extension due to complete rupture.
  • MRI would show a complete tear of the tendon with disruption of fibers, which is more gradual onset with activity-related pain.

 

 

  • The acute nature and complete loss of function would be inconsistent with the gradual, activity-related pain in this patient.

 

Option B. Osgood-Schlatter Disease:

 

  • Osgood-Schlatter disease is a traction apophysitis that occurs during the growth spurt of adolescence (usually 10-15 years old).
  • It involves the tibial tuberosity, not the patellar tendon, and presents with pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity.
  • This condition is more common in growing adolescents and is self-limiting once the growth plates close.
  • MRI findings would show inflammation or ossification at the tibial tuberosity, not at the inferior pole of the patella.

 

 

  • The tenderness in Osgood-Schlatter is localized to the tibial tuberosity, whereas the patient in the case has pain at the inferior pole of the patella.

 

Option D. Hoffa’s Fat Pad Impingement:

 

  • Hoffa’s fat pad impingement (also known as patellar fat pad syndrome) occurs when the infrapatellar fat pad becomes pinched or irritated, often due to trauma, overuse, or repetitive flexion-extension movements.
  • The patient experiences anterior knee pain, particularly with activities that involve knee extension or deep flexion, but the pain is usually around the patellar tendon and joint line, not specifically at the inferior pole of the patella.
  • MRI might show fat pad edema or inflammation, but it doesn’t usually cause the same localized tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella as seen in Jumper’s Knee.

 

 

  • Although both conditions cause anterior knee pain, the localized tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella is more characteristic of Jumper's Knee rather than Hoffa’s fat pad impingement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patellar tendon rupture – acute, with loss of function, not gradual pain.
  • Osgood-Schlatter disease – affects tibial tuberosity, common in adolescents, not in adults.
  • Jumper’s knee – chronic tendinopathy due to overuse in jumping sports, with tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella.
  • Hoffa’s fat pad impingement – anterior knee pain with activity, but usually no localized tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella.

questions.text: Based on the given image and child presenting with delayed dentition, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cleidocranial Dysostosis

 

  • Cleidocranial Dysostosis (CCD) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the RUNX2 gene, affecting bone and dental development.
  • Key clinical features include: 
    • Delayed closure of fontanelles, resulting in frontal bossing.
    • Clavicular hypoplasia or absence, allowing hypermobility of shoulders (as seen in the image).
    • Delayed eruption of primary and permanent teeth.
    • Multiple supernumerary teeth, leading to dental crowding and abnormalities.
    • Short stature and narrow thorax.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Rickets: Rickets is incorrect because it primarily affects bone mineralization and presents with skeletal deformities such as bowing of the legs, widening of costochondral junctions ("rachitic rosary"), and craniotabes. The characteristic findings of clavicular hypoplasia, dental abnormalities, and shoulder hypermobility seen in Cleidocranial Dysostosis are absent in rickets.

 

Option B. Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia is incorrect because it is characterized by short-limbed dwarfism, macrocephaly, and midface hypoplasia. While both conditions involve skeletal abnormalities, achondroplasia does not present with clavicular hypoplasia or delayed dentition with supernumerary teeth, which are hallmarks of Cleidocranial Dysostosis.

 

Option D. Incontinentia Pigmenti: Incontinentia Pigmenti is incorrect because it is a genetic ectodermal dysplasia disorder presenting with skin changes (blistering, hyperpigmentation, and scarring), alopecia, and nail abnormalities. It does not cause clavicular hypoplasia or dental abnormalities like those seen in Cleidocranial Dysostosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cleidocranial Dysostosis (CCD) is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia affecting the skull, clavicles, and teeth.
  • Key features include hypoplastic or absent clavicles, delayed dentition, supernumerary teeth, and frontal bossing.
  • Diagnosis is clinical but can be confirmed with X-rays showing clavicular hypoplasia and delayed ossification centers.

questions.text:
Match List I (Important Events) with List II (Main Hormone Responsible). 

 

List I (Important Events):

 

  1. Initiation of LH surge
  2. Preventing luteolysis of corpus luteum
  3. Initiation of ovarian cycle
  4. Luteal phase defect

 

List II (Main Hormone Responsible):

 

  1. Progesterone
  2. hCG
  3. FSH
  4. Estrogen
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-4, B-2, C-3, D-1

 

A-4. Initiation of LH surge → Estrogen:Estrogen causes a positive feedback effect on the hypothalamus and pituitary, leading to a surge in LH, which triggers ovulation.

 

B-2. Preventing luteolysis of corpus luteum → hCG: hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is secreted by the trophoblast cells of the early embryo and prevents the corpus luteum from undergoing luteolysis, ensuring continued progesterone production in early pregnancy.

 

C-3. Initiation of ovarian cycle → FSH:FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) is responsible for the recruitment and maturation of ovarian follicles, initiating the ovarian cycle.

 

D-1. Luteal phase defect → Progesterone: A luteal phase defect occurs when the corpus luteum fails to produce sufficient progesterone, leading to implantation failure and menstrual irregularities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Estrogen triggers the LH surge that induces ovulation.
  • hCG maintains the corpus luteum and prevents luteolysis in early pregnancy.
  • FSH is responsible for follicular recruitment and the initiation of the ovarian cycle.
  • Progesterone deficiency results in luteal phase defects, affecting implantation and pregnancy maintenance.

choices.text: Increased venous return due to muscle pump action
Decreased splanchnic blood flow due to sympathetic vasoconstriction
Increased coronary blood flow mediated by local metabolic vasodilation
Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is undergoing a cardiovascular stress test. During exercise, his oxygen consumption increases significantly, leading to an enhanced cardiac output and redistribution of blood flow. Which of the following changes is least likely to occur in response to the increased metabolic demand?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction

 

Increased TPR:  Incorrect.

 

  • TPR actually decreases during exercise due to vasodilation in skeletal muscles (despite vasoconstriction in non-exercising tissues).
  • If TPR increased significantly, it would reduce cardiac output and impair oxygen delivery, which does not happen physiologically.

 

Other Options:

 

During exercise, cardiovascular and metabolic adaptations occur to ensure oxygen delivery to active muscles. The following responses are observed:

 

Option A. Increased venous return due to muscle pump action: True.

 

  • The muscle pump and respiratory pump enhance venous return, leading to increased preload and cardiac output via the Frank-Starling mechanism.

 

Option B. Decreased splanchnic blood flow due to sympathetic vasoconstriction: True.

 

  • Sympathetic stimulation leads to vasoconstriction in non-essential areas like the gut and kidneys, diverting blood to exercising muscles.

 

Option C. Increased coronary blood flow mediated by local metabolic vasodilation: True.

 

  • Local metabolic vasodilation (adenosine, nitric oxide, and hypoxia-mediated) increases coronary perfusion to meet myocardial oxygen demand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During exercise, vasodilation in active muscles lowers total peripheral resistance (TPR) despite sympathetic-mediated vasoconstriction in other regions. 
  • The primary cardiovascular adaptations include increased cardiac output, redistribution of blood flow, and enhanced oxygen delivery to meet metabolic demand.

questions.text: The dashed line in the figure illustrates the effect of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased blood volume

 

More blood volume increases venous return, shifting the venous return curve to the right, which is what the dashed line represents.

 

The figure represents the cardiac function (Frank-Starling) curve and venous return curve, which together determine the equilibrium cardiac output (CO) and right atrial pressure (RAP).

 

The dashed curve shows an upward shift of the venous return curve, which occurs when blood volume increases. The venous return curve shifts to the right, meaning increased preload and mean systemic filling pressure (Pmsf). This results in:

 

  • Increased right atrial pressure (RAP)
  • Increased cardiac output (CO)
  • Increased venous return

 

Effects of Increased Blood Volume:

 

  • More circulating blood volume leads to increased venous return.
  • Higher preload stretches the cardiac muscle, enhancing stroke volume by the Frank-Starling mechanism.
  • The cardiac output increases as a response to the increased venous return.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR): Incorrect.

 

  • Increased TPR decreases venous return and shifts the cardiac output curve downward, not the venous return curve.

 

Option C. Decreased contractility: Incorrect.

 

  • This would cause a downward shift of the cardiac output curve, as the heart pumps less efficiently. The dashed line, however, shows an upward shift in cardiac output, not a decline—so this is incorrect.

 

Option D. A negative inotropic agent: Incorrect.

 

  • A negative inotropic effect (e.g., heart failure) would decrease cardiac function but not shift the venous return curve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Increased blood volume shifts the venous return curve to the right, increasing right atrial pressure and cardiac output. 
  • This occurs due to greater circulating volume and increased mean systemic filling pressure, which enhances venous return to the heart.

questions.text:
Match List I (Scores) with List II (Condition in which it is used).


List I (Scores)

 

  1. Insler score
  2. Nugent score
  3. Boer Meisel score
  4. Ferriman Gallwey score


List II (Condition in which it is used)

 

  1. Bacterial vaginosis
  2. Trichomonas vaginitis
  3. Cervical mucus
  4. Hirsutism
  5. Alopecia
  6. Pregnancy prognosis of tubal infertility
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-1, C-6, D-4

 

A-3. Insler score → Cervical mucus: Insler score assesses cervical mucus quality, which is crucial for sperm penetration and fertility evaluation.


B-1. Nugent score → Bacterial vaginosis: Nugent score is used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV) based on a Gram stain scoring system assessing bacterial morphotypes.


C-6. Boer Meisel score → Pregnancy prognosis of tubal infertility: Boer Meisel score evaluates endometrial receptivity and pregnancy prognosis in cases of tubal infertility.


D-4. Ferriman Gallwey score → Hirsutism: Ferriman Gallwey score is used to grade the severity of hirsutism, a condition seen in PCOS and other androgen excess disorders.


Educational Objective: 

 

  • Insler score evaluates cervical mucus quality for fertility assessment.
  • Nugent score is a microscopic scoring system for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis.
  • Boer Meisel score assesses endometrial receptivity and pregnancy prognosis in tubal infertility.
  • Ferriman Gallwey score measures hirsutism severity, often used in PCOS evaluation.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Supraglottic Airway Devices


Column A (Devices)

 

  1. LMA Supreme
  2. LMA Proseal
  3. LMA Fastrach
  4. Ambu AURA40


Column B (Features)

 

A. First-generation device
B. Special LMA 
C. Single-use second-generation device
D. Multiple-use second-generation device
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. LMA Supreme → C. Single-use second-generation device

 

  • The LMA Supreme is a second-generation supraglottic airway device designed with improvements over the classic LMA.
  • It includes a gastric drainage channel, increasing safety in terms of aspiration risk.
  • However, it is single-use, making it ideal for infection control and cost-effectiveness in certain settings.

 

2. LMA Proseal → D. Multiple-use second-generation device

 

  • The LMA Proseal is a reusable second-generation device.
  • It has a drain tube for gastric contents and better sealing pressures, allowing positive pressure ventilation.
  • It is designed for repeated use after proper sterilization.

 

3. LMA Fastrach → B. Special LMA

 

  • The LMA Fastrach (also called the intubating LMA) is considered a specialized LMA.
  • It is used to facilitate blind endotracheal intubation, especially in difficult airway scenarios.
  • Its design includes a rigid curved tube and handle to aid in tube placement.

 

4. Ambu AURA40 → A. First-generation device

 

  • The Ambu AURA40 is a first-generation LMA.
  • It lacks a gastric channel and is intended for basic airway management.
  • It is reusable, but lacks the advanced features (e.g., drainage tube) found in second-generation devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • LMA Supreme → Single-use second-generation device
  • LMA Proseal → Multiple-use second-generation device
  • LMA Fastrach → Special LMA designed for intubation
  • Ambu AURA40 → First-generation device

questions.text: A 55-year-old man admitted to the ICU for septic shock on vasopressor support suddenly develops hypotension and altered sensorium. His extremities are cold and central venous pressure is elevated. POCUS findings are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Massive pulmonary embolism

 

The patient presents with obstructive shock in the ICU setting. POCUS (Point of Care Ultrasound) shows a D-shaped left ventricle suggestive of right ventricular pressure overload, typical of massive PE. Elevated CVP, cold extremities, and sudden deterioration are consistent with PE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute coronary syndrome: Would not explain elevated CVP and sudden collapse unless involving massive infarct.

 

Option B. Tension pneumothorax: Would present with unilateral chest findings and tracheal shift.

 

Option D. Cardiac tamponade: Echo would show pericardial effusion and right atrial/ventricular diastolic collapse.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In ICU patients with obstructive shock and POCUS showing RV overload, massive pulmonary embolism must be suspected.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for fatigue, low-grade fever, joint pain, and a newly detected positive anti-histone antibody on serologic testing. His symptoms began several weeks after starting a new medication. He has no known autoimmune history. Among the drugs listed below, which is least likely to be responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amphetamine

 

This patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE), a lupus-like syndrome typically triggered by certain medications. The hallmark of DILE includes arthralgia, fatigue, fever, serositis, and positive anti-histone antibodies.

 

Drugs classically associated with DILE include:

 

  • Isoniazid: Used in tuberculosis treatment; known cause of DILE.
  • Procainamide: A class Ia antiarrhythmic drug; one of the highest risk medications for DILE.
  • Hydralazine: An antihypertensive that can induce lupus, especially in slow acetylators.

 

However, Amphetamine is not associated with drug-induced lupus. It is a central nervous system stimulant used to treat ADHD and narcolepsy but does not share any immunologic mechanism that triggers DILE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydralazine: Incorrect, Hydralazine is a known cause of DILE. Its risk is higher in slow acetylators, and it commonly presents with fever, joint pain, and positive anti-histone antibodies.

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Incorrect, Isoniazid, widely used in tuberculosis prophylaxis and treatment, is a documented trigger of drug-induced lupus, especially after prolonged use.

 

Option D. Procainamide: Incorrect, Procainamide is a high-risk agent for DILE. It interferes with immune tolerance and frequently results in lupus-like syndrome after long-term use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydralazine, isoniazid, and procainamide are commonly associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, which is often confirmed by the presence of anti-histone antibodies. Amphetamine is not linked to this condition.

choices.text: Transvaginal ultrasound scan for follicular tracking

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who has been infertile for 3 years presents to the clinic. She reports frequent, painful periods with dysmenorrhea, which is most severe on the third day of menstruation. She also complains of deep dyspareunia. Her Day 21 progesterone level is 32 nmol/L, and her partner’s semen analysis is normal. Which of the following investigations should be performed next?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diagnostic Laparoscopy

 

Key clinical features (dysmenorrhea, deep dyspareunia, and infertility) suggest endometriosis.

 

  • Day 21 progesterone >30 nmol/L confirms ovulation, indicating that anovulation is not the cause of infertility.
  • A normal seminal fluid analysis rules out male factor infertility.
  • Endometriosis is best diagnosed via laparoscopy, which also allows a dye test to assess tubal patency.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Hysterosalpingogram:HSG is useful for assessing tubal patency but does not diagnose endometriosis, which is suspected here.


Option B. Hysteroscopy: Hysteroscopy evaluates intrauterine abnormalities (polyps, fibroids, adhesions) but does not diagnose peritoneal factors like endometriosis.


Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound scan for follicular tracking:Ovulation is already confirmed by Day 21 progesterone levels, making follicular tracking unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endometriosis should be suspected in women with infertility, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia.
  • Diagnostic Laparoscopy with dye test is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and assessing tubal patency.
  • HSG is useful for tubal assessment but does not detect peritoneal disease.
  • A normal Day 21 progesterone level confirms ovulation, ruling out anovulatory causes of infertility.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with acute diarrhea, signs of dehydration, and altered electrolytes. Laboratory investigations reveal Na+ 125 mEq/L, K+ 3 mEq/L, HCO₃⁻ 16 mEq/L, and pH 7.23.Which of the following IV fluids should be administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal saline (0.9% NaCl)

 

The child presents with dehydration, hyponatremia (Na+ 125), and metabolic acidosis (HCO₃⁻ 16, pH 7.23).

 

  • Acute diarrhea leads to fluid loss, hypovolemia, and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Metabolic acidosis occurs due to hypovolemia-induced lactic acidosis and bicarbonate loss in diarrhea.

 

The best fluid choice in this scenario is an isotonic fluid that corrects dehydration and metabolic acidosis.

 

Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) is the preferred IV fluid as it: 

 

  • Restores intravascular volume.
  • Corrects hyponatremia without causing rapid shifts.
  • Helps reverse metabolic acidosis by improving perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 3% saline: (Hypertonic saline) is incorrect.

 

  • Indicated for severe symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., seizures, altered consciousness).
  • Not required in mild to moderate hyponatremia (Na+ 125) with dehydration, as rapid sodium correction can cause osmotic demyelination syndrome.

 

Option C. N/3 saline + 10% dextrose: is incorrect.

 

  • Hypotonic fluids are avoided in dehydration as they can cause further hyponatremia and cerebral edema.

 

Option D. N/3 saline + 5% dextrose: is incorrect.

 

  • Again, hypotonic solutions are not appropriate in rehydration therapy.
  • Dextrose alone does not correct dehydration and can worsen hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) is the IV fluid of choice for dehydration with hyponatremia and metabolic acidosis.
  • Avoid hypotonic fluids (e.g., N/3 saline, dextrose-containing solutions) in dehydration to prevent further sodium imbalance.
  • 3% saline is reserved for severe symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., seizures), not for mild to moderate cases.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents with anterior neck pain, low-grade fever, and fatigue for the past week. She reports that the pain radiates to her jaw and worsens with swallowing. On examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and exquisitely tender to palpation. Labs show:

 

  • Elevated free T4
  • Suppressed TSH
  • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  • Low radioactive iodine uptake on scan

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis

 

The above-described condition is Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (Also known as de Quervain thyroiditis). This condition typically presents after a viral upper respiratory infection, followed by painful thyroid inflammation, often with transient thyrotoxicosis due to follicular cell destruction and release of preformed thyroid hormones.

 

Key findings that support this diagnosis:

 

  • Painful, tender thyroid gland
  • Elevated ESR (inflammatory marker)
  • Thyrotoxicosis with high free T4 and low TSH
  • Low radioactive iodine uptake (due to hormone leakage, not increased synthesis)
  • Histologically: multinucleated giant cells and granulomatous inflammation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riedel thyroiditis: Incorrect. This is a rare fibrosing condition of the thyroid that presents with a hard, woody, fixed thyroid mass, but it is typically painless and associated with fibrosis extending beyond the gland.

 

Option B. Suppurative (bacterial) thyroiditis: Incorrect. This condition also presents with pain, but is usually seen in immunocompromised individuals or those with preexisting thyroid disease. It often shows abscess formation and marked leukocytosis, which are not seen here.

 

Option D. Toxic multinodular goiter: Incorrect. Presents with thyrotoxicosis, but the gland is nontender, and the condition evolves gradually, not acutely. The radioactive iodine uptake would typically be increased or patchy, not low.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis is a self-limited, painful thyroid condition that follows viral illness. It causes transient thyrotoxicosis with low radioactive iodine uptake and is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with giant cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating, and fatigue. Her labs show iron-deficiency anemia and mildly elevated liver enzymes. Serologic testing reveals IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG). Duodenal biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Celiac disease

 

  • Celiac disease is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by gluten exposure in genetically susceptible individuals. This condition is diagnosed using a combination of serology and histology:
  • IgA antibodies against endomysium, tissue transglutaminase (tTG), or gliadin are highly sensitive and specific.
  • IgG antibodies (particularly anti-gliadin) are also present and useful in individuals with IgA deficiency, which is more common in patients with celiac disease.
  • Biopsy from the duodenum (most prominently affected site) shows:
    • Flattened villi
    • Crypt hyperplasia
    • Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes
    • Jejunum and ileum are typically less involved compared to the duodenum.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Crohn disease: Crohn disease may affect the small intestine but shows transmural inflammation, non-caseating granulomas, and skip lesions, not the villous flattening or IgA-based autoantibodies typical of celiac disease.

 

Option B. Whipple disease: Caused by Tropheryma whipplei, it presents with PAS-positive foamy macrophages in the lamina propria. It does not show villous atrophy, crypt 

 

Option D. Tropical sprue: This condition may mimic celiac histologically but typically involves the jejunum and ileum more than the duodenum. Also, it lacks anti-endomysial or anti-tTG antibodies and responds to antibiotics rather than gluten withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Celiac disease is diagnosed by IgA (or IgG) antibodies against tTG, endomysium, or gliadin, and confirmed by duodenal biopsy showing villous flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. 
  • The duodenum is most affected, with jejunum and ileum less involved.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Raloxifene is incorrect? 

 

  1. Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as an estrogen agonist on bone.
  2. It increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma similar to tamoxifen.
  3. Raloxifene reduces vertebral fracture risk but has no proven benefit for hip fracture prevention.
  4. It acts as an estrogen antagonist on breast and uterine tissue.
  5. Raloxifene is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only statement 2 is incorrect

 

2. It increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma similar to tamoxifen: Incorrect. Unlike tamoxifen, Raloxifene acts as an estrogen antagonist on endometrial tissue, so it does not increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. In contrast, tamoxifen increases this risk.

 

Correct Statements:

 

1. Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as an estrogen agonist on bone: Correct. Raloxifene is a SERM that acts as an estrogen agonist on bone, improving bone mineral density and reducing vertebral fracture risk in postmenopausal women.

 

3. Raloxifene reduces vertebral fracture risk but has no proven benefit for hip fracture prevention: Correct. Raloxifene reduces the risk of vertebral fractures, but unlike bisphosphonates, it has no significant effect on hip fracture prevention.

 

4. It acts as an estrogen antagonist on breast and uterine tissue: Correct. Raloxifene is an estrogen antagonist in breast and uterine tissue, which contributes to its protective role against breast cancer and no increased risk of endometrial cancer.

 

5. Raloxifene is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism: Correct. like other estrogenic agents, Raloxifene increases the risk of venous thromboembolism, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.


Educational Objective:

 

Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that acts as an estrogen agonist on bone and antagonist on breast and endometrium. Unlike tamoxifen, it does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer. It is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman, G2P2, undergoes a normal vaginal delivery but develops severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) despite an intact placenta. The uterus is soft and boggy, indicating uterine atony. Uterine massage and oxytocin administration fail to control the bleeding. Arrange the following steps in the correct order for managing atonic PPH not responding to uterine massage: 

 

  1. Oxytocin infusion
  2. Ligation of the uterine artery
  3. B-Lynch compression suture
  4. Tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 - 4 - 3 - 2

 

The correct stepwise approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is:

 

Step 1. Medical Management with uterotonics.

 

Step 2. Mechanical Methods: This includes bimanual uterine compression, intra

 

Step 3. B-Lynch suture: If bleeding continues, perform uterine compression sutures (B-Lynch technique).

 

Step 4. Stepwise devascularization

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Stepwise management of PPH: 
    1. Medical management with oxytocics 
    2. Mechanical methods including intra uterine balloon tamponade
    3. Compression sutures (B-Lynch)
    4. Stepwise devascularization (uterine artery, utero-ovarian and ant div of internal iliac)
  • Early intervention is crucial to prevent maternal morbidity and mortality.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Ringertz tumor are true? 

 

  1. It is a benign neoplasm arising from the Schneiderian membrane of the nose and paranasal sinuses.
  2. The most common site of origin is the lateral nasal wall near the middle meatus.
  3. It is usually bilateral and frequently associated with allergic rhinitis.
  4. The gold standard treatment is medial maxillectomy, preferably via an endoscopic approach.
  5. Radiotherapy is the primary treatment of choice to prevent recurrence.
  6. Up to 15% of cases may undergo malignant transformation, most commonly into squamous cell carcinoma.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

1. Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor) is a benign neoplasm arising from the Schneiderian membrane of the nose and paranasal sinuses. 

 

  • It originates from the Schneiderian epithelium, which is the non-olfactory mucosa of the nasal cavity.

 

2. The most common site of origin is the lateral nasal wall near the middle meatus. 

 

  • The tumor frequently arises from the lateral nasal wall in the middle meatus and extends into the sinuses.

 

4. The gold standard treatment is medial maxillectomy, preferably via an endoscopic approach. 

 

  • Endoscopic medial maxillectomy is the preferred treatment to reduce recurrence rates.

 

6. Up to 15% of cases may undergo malignant transformation, most commonly into squamous cell carcinoma. 

 

  • Malignant transformation occurs in 10-15% of cases, most commonly into squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

3. Inverted papilloma is usually bilateral and frequently associated with allergic rhinitis.

 

  • False. It is almost always unilateral and has no association with allergic rhinitis.

 

5. Radiotherapy is the primary treatment of choice to prevent recurrence.

 

  • False. Radiotherapy is NOT recommended as it may induce malignant transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor) is a benign but locally aggressive sinonasal tumor.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction with epistaxis is a key symptom.
  • Endoscopic medial maxillectomy is the preferred treatment due to high recurrence rates and malignant potential.
  • Radiotherapy is avoided as it may lead to malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male with localized prostate cancer is scheduled for robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP) using a da Vinci surgical system. The surgical team discusses the advantages, limitations, and technical considerations of robotic surgery. Which of the following statements about robotic surgery is true? 

 

  1. Robotic-assisted surgery eliminates the need for pneumoperitoneum, making it safer for patients with cardiopulmonary compromise.
  2. The master-slave telemanipulation system allows the surgeon to control robotic arms with enhanced precision and motion scaling.
  3. Robotic surgery provides 3D high-definition vision, wristed instruments with 7 degrees of freedom, and tremor filtration.
  4. Haptic feedback is a major advantage of current robotic systems, allowing the surgeon to feel tissue resistance.
  5. Robotic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays, less blood loss, and faster recovery compared to open surgery.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 5

 

2. The master-slave telemanipulation system allows the surgeon to control robotic arms with enhanced precision and motion scaling:  True,

 

  • Surgeon’s control robotic arms remotely using a master console, providing motion scaling, improved dexterity, and reduced physiological tremors.

     

3. Robotic surgery provides 3D high-definition vision, wristed instruments with 7 degrees of freedom, and tremor filtration: True,

 

  • Robotic systems offer superior visualization with high-definition 3D imaging, which is a major advantage over standard laparoscopy.
  • Wristed instruments provide enhanced dexterity with 7 degrees of motion (compared to human hands with only 5 degrees).

     

5. Robotic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays, less blood loss, and faster recovery compared to open surgery: True,

 

Studies show less blood loss, shorter hospitalization, and faster return to daily activities in robotic vs. open surgery, particularly in prostatectomy, gynecologic, and colorectal procedures.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

1. Robotic-assisted surgery eliminates the need for pneumoperitoneum, making it safer for patients with cardiopulmonary compromise: False,

 

  • Pneumoperitoneum is still required in robotic surgery, just like in conventional laparoscopy.
  • CO₂ insufflation can still pose risks to patients with cardiopulmonary conditions (e.g., reduced venous return, hypercarbia).

 

4. Haptic feedback is a major advantage of current robotic systems, allowing the surgeon to feel tissue resistance: False,

 

  • Most current robotic systems lack haptic (tactile) feedback, meaning surgeons must rely on visual cues to judge tissue tension.
  • Some newer systems (e.g., Senhance) are integrating haptic feedback, but it is not yet a standard feature.


Educational Objective:
 

  • Robotic surgery enhances precision, dexterity, and visualization but still requires pneumoperitoneum.
  • Lack of haptic feedback is a major limitation, requiring reliance on visual cues.
  • Advantages include 3D vision, motion scaling, tremor filtration, and shorter recovery times.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with newly diagnosed schizophrenia presents for pharmacologic management. He has a history of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and a strong family history of coronary artery disease. The physician chooses an antipsychotic with low risk of weight gain and minimal metabolic side effects. However, the medication requires caution due to its potential to prolong the QT interval. Which of the following agents was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

 

Ziprasidone is a second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic known for:

 

  • Low risk of weight gain and metabolic syndrome
  • Dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptor antagonism
  • Risk of QT interval prolongation, which may predispose to torsades de pointes

 

Because of its favorable metabolic profile, Ziprasidone is preferred in patients who are overweight, diabetic, or have cardiovascular risk factors. However, it should be avoided in individuals with preexisting QT prolongation or those taking other QT-prolonging drugs.


Other Options: 

 

Option A. Olanzapine:  Highly effective but associated with significant weight gain, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia.

 

Option B. Risperidone:  Can cause elevated prolactin levels and moderate metabolic side effects. QT prolongation is less significant compared to Ziprasidone.

 

Option D. Clozapine:  Reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. High risk of metabolic syndrome, agranulocytosis, and seizures.


Educational Objective:

 

Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic with minimal metabolic side effects, making it suitable for patients at risk for weight gain and diabetes. However, its use is limited by the risk of QT interval prolongation.
