questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a periampullary carcinoma is scheduled for a Pancreaticoduodenectomy. Which of the following represents the correct steps in the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 

 

  1. Mobilization of duodenum and division of pancreas at the neck
  2. Cholecystectomy & division of bile duct
  3. Gastric/duodenal transection
  4. Reconstruction (Pancreaticojejunostomy, Hepaticojejunostomy, Gastrojejunostomy)

 

Correct Steps of Whipple’s Procedure Steps:

 

1️. Division of pancreas at the neck:

 

  • The pancreas is transected first, which allows for controlled mobilization of the duodenum and pancreatic head.

     

2️. Cholecystectomy & division of the common bile duct:

 

  • The gallbladder and bile duct are removed to facilitate bile drainage into the jejunum later.

     

3️. Mobilization of the duodenum & head of pancreas (Kocher maneuver): 

 

  • The duodenum and pancreatic head are freed from retroperitoneal attachments.

     

4️. Gastric/duodenal transection:

 

  • If a pylorus-preserving Whipple is performed, the duodenum is transected.
  • If not, the distal stomach is resected (classic Whipple).

     

5️. Reconstruction Phase:

 

  • Pancreaticojejunostomy (Pancreatic anastomosis to jejunum).
  • Hepaticojejunostomy (Biliary anastomosis to jejunum).
  • Gastrojejunostomy (Gastric anastomosis to jejunum for continuity).

 

 

Educational Objective 
 

  • Whipple’s procedure is a complex pancreaticoduodenectomy performed for periampullary and pancreatic head tumors.
  • The procedure involves resection followed by reconstruction, and the sequence is crucial for surgical success.

questions.text: In a study comparing the recovery rates of two different rehabilitation programs for stroke patients, patients were randomly assigned to one of two groups. Which test is best suited to compare the ordinal scale outcomes between these two independent groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wilcoxon rank-sum test

 

  • The Wilcoxon rank-sum test, also known as the Mann-Whitney U test, is ideal for comparing ordinal or continuous data between two independent groups. 
  • This non-parametric test is used when the data are not normally distributed and involves ranking all the data points together and then comparing the ranks between the two groups. 
  • It is particularly useful in medical studies where the data may not follow a normal distribution, as is often the case with clinical outcomes measured on ordinal scales.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilcoxon signed-rank test: This test is used for comparing paired or matched samples, such as measurements taken from the same subjects before and after a treatment. It is not suitable for this scenario because the groups are independent.

 

Option C. Chi-square test: Typically used for categorical data to test relationships between variables. Not suitable for ordinal or continuous outcomes.

 

Option D. Sign test: This test is used for comparing median values of paired data, not applicable for independent groups as in this study scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When conducting studies with two independent groups where data are ordinal or not normally distributed, the Wilcoxon rank-sum test provides a reliable method for assessing differences. 
  • It avoids the assumptions of normality required by parametric tests and is more powerful than other non-parametric alternatives for independent samples.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Castroviejo caliper

 

  • The image shows a Castroviejo caliper, a precision surgical instrument used commonly in ophthalmic procedures for accurate measurement of small distances, especially during intraocular surgeries like cataract extraction or corneal transplant. 
  • It allows measurements typically from 0 to 20 mm with high precision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Graefe knife: This is a thin, straight knife historically used for cataract surgeries, not a measuring instrument.

 

 

Option B. Keratome: A keratome is used to make incisions in the cornea, particularly during cataract surgery — it does not resemble the caliper shown.

 

 

Option C. Bowman's probe: This is a thin, blunt-ended instrument used for probing nasolacrimal ducts, not for measurements.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Castroviejo calipers are precision instruments used in ophthalmic surgery for accurate intraoperative measurements. 
  • Recognizing surgical tools by appearance is essential for both surgical preparation and examination identification.

questions.text: A researcher studying amino acid metabolism isolates an enzyme that can function in both oxidative deamination and reductive amination reactions. He observes that the enzyme is versatile in electron transfer, as it can utilize both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors depending on cellular needs. Which of the following enzymes exhibits this cofactor flexibility?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamate dehydrogenase

 

  • Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) catalyzes the oxidative deamination of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate, and vice versa.
  • Uniquely, it can use both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as hydrogen acceptors, depending on the cell's metabolic state:
    • NAD⁺ in catabolic conditions (ATP generation)
    • NADP⁺ in anabolic reactions (e.g., biosynthesis)
  • This dual coenzyme use makes GDH flexible in energy and nitrogen metabolism, especially in liver and kidney tissue.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Uses NAD⁺ exclusively as a cofactor to convert pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. It does not use NADP⁺.

 

Option C. Glutathione reductase: Requires NADPH to reduce oxidized glutathione (GSSG) to its reduced form (GSH). It does not use NAD⁺.

 

Option D. Lactate dehydrogenase: Uses NAD⁺ to convert lactate to pyruvate (and vice versa). It cannot use NADP⁺.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutamate dehydrogenase is the only enzyme among the options that can use both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors, depending on the metabolic context.

questions.text: What is the primary indication for the use of this technique?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fistula-in-ano


A seton is a surgical thread or suture used to facilitate the gradual drainage and healing of a fistula-in-ano while minimizing the risk of fecal incontinence. It is primarily indicated in high anal fistulas, particularly those involving the sphincter complex, where simple fistulotomy could lead to sphincter damage.


Types of seton use:

 

  • Cutting seton – Gradually tightens to slowly divide the sphincter while allowing fibrosis.
  • Draining seton – Helps drain pus and prevents abscess formation in complex or multiple fistulas.


Other options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are managed with banding, sclerotherapy, or hemorrhoidectomy, not a seton.


Option B. Anal fissure: Anal fissures are treated with topical nitro-glycerine, lateral internal sphincterotomy, or Botox, but do not require seton placement.


Option D. Rectal prolapse: Rectal prolapse is corrected surgically with rectopexy or perineal procedures; setons have no role in its management.


Educational Objective:


A seton is used in the management of high or complex anal fistulas to prevent incontinence by allowing gradual fibrosis while preserving sphincter function. It is particularly useful in fistulas involving the sphincter complex.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and well-controlled hypertension is evaluated for elevated lipid levels. His fasting lipid profile shows:

 

  • Total cholesterol: 205 mg/dL
  • LDL-C: 100 mg/dL
  • HDL-C: 42 mg/dL
  • Triglycerides: 690 mg/dL

 

He has no history of pancreatitis but reports intermittent abdominal discomfort. He is currently taking metformin and lisinopril. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to reduce this patient’s triglyceride level and prevent pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fenofibrate

 

  • This patient has severe hypertriglyceridemia (TG > 500 mg/dL), putting him at increased risk of acute pancreatitis. The primary goal is triglyceride reduction.
  • Fenofibrate is a fibric acid derivative that activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPAR-α). This increases lipoprotein lipase activity, enhancing the clearance of triglyceride-rich particles (VLDL), and significantly lowers triglyceride levels.
  • Fenofibrate is the first-line agent for patients at risk of pancreatitis due to elevated triglycerides.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: Primarily lowers LDL cholesterol and has modest effect on triglycerides. Statins are first line for cardiovascular risk, but not for very high TG when pancreatitis risk is a concern.

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption, reducing LDL-C but has minimal effect on triglycerides. Not suitable for TG lowering.

 

Option D. Alirocumab: A PCSK9 inhibitor, significantly lowers LDL-C but has no role in lowering triglycerides or preventing pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fenofibrate is the drug of choice for patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia (>500 mg/dL) to reduce the risk of acute pancreatitis. It works by activating PPAR-α to enhance triglyceride metabolism.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with sudden right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He has no history of hypertension, diabetes, or smoking. Examination shows right hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. MRI of the brain is shown. Echocardiography reveals a patent foramen ovale (PFO). No atherosclerotic disease is found on vascular imaging. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antiplatelet therapy

 

  • MRI shows an infarct in the left ganglio-capsular region. PFO closure is typically reserved for patients <60 years with cryptogenic stroke and no other identifiable cause. 
  • This patient is older, and stroke management focuses on antiplatelet therapy in such cases. Embolic pattern alone in imaging is insufficient to justify closure in elderly without a clear indication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anticoagulation with DOAC: Not preferred unless there’s concurrent AF or DVT.

 

Option C. Surgical PFO closure: Indicated in younger patients with an embolic pattern on imaging and no other alternative etiology for stroke. 

 

Option D. Statins and lifestyle changes: Useful adjunct but not definitive secondary prevention for embolic stroke.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

PFO closure is recommended only in patients <60 years with cryptogenic embolic stroke and no alternate cause; antiplatelet therapy is standard in older patients.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and early satiety. Physical examination reveals massive splenomegaly, but no lymphadenopathy. CBC shows pancytopenia. Bone marrow aspiration results in a dry tap. A peripheral smear demonstrates lymphocytes with abundant pale cytoplasm and fine, hair-like cytoplasmic projections. The neoplastic cells are positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL)

 

  • Hairy Cell Leukemia is a rare chronic B-cell neoplasm characterized by:
    • Neoplastic proliferation of mature B cells with hair-like cytoplasmic projections on smear
    • TRAP-positive staining (tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase), which is a historical but distinctive marker
    • Massive splenomegaly, especially due to infiltration of the red pulp, as opposed to white pulp seen in most other lymphomas
    • Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration due to marrow fibrosis, a classic feature
    • Pancytopenia from bone marrow suppression
    • Absence of lymphadenopathy, which helps differentiate it from other leukemias and lymphomas

 

These clinical, morphological, and staining features make Hairy Cell Leukemia the correct diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): Presents with lymphocytosis, smudge cells, and often generalized lymphadenopathy—which are not seen in this case.

 

Option B. Follicular lymphoma: Typically involves painless lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly is less prominent. Cells are CD10+, and there are no hairy projections or dry tap.

 

Option D. Mantle cell lymphoma: Often involves lymph nodes, GI tract, and may present with cyclin D1 overexpression, but lacks hairy projections or TRAP positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy Cell Leukemia is a B-cell malignancy characterized by cytoplasmic projections, TRAP positivity, splenomegaly, dry tap on marrow aspiration, and typically no lymphadenopathy.

questions.text:
A researcher is studying the effects of two different enzyme inhibitors, A and B, on the activity of an enzyme involved in a metabolic pathway. The researcher observes the following:
 

  • Inhibitor A increases the Km (Michaelis constant) of the enzyme without affecting the Vmax (maximum velocity).
  • Inhibitor B decreases the Vmax without changing the Km.

     

Based on these observations, the researcher classifies the types of inhibition.

 

What is the most likely classification of Inhibitor A and Inhibitor B?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

 

  • Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor A): In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. 
  • This leads to an increase in Km (indicating reduced affinity for the substrate) but does not alter the Vmax because increasing substrate concentration can overcome the inhibition.
  • Observation: Inhibitor A raises Km without changing Vmax — characteristic of competitive inhibition.
  • Non-competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor B): Non-competitive inhibitors bind to other than active site. This binding can occur regardless of whether the substrate is bound or not. Non-competitive inhibition decreases the Vmax (reducing the maximum enzyme activity) without changing the Km, as it does not affect substrate binding.
  • Observation: Inhibitor B reduces Vmax without altering Km — characteristic of non-competitive inhibition.

     

Note: Uncompetitive inhibitors reduce both Km and Vmax. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inhibitor A: Competitive (increases Km, no effect on Vmax)
  • Inhibitor B: Non-competitive (decreases Vmax, no effect on Km)

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought for a routine pediatric check-up. The pediatrician assesses his growth, dentition, and motor milestones. Which of the following statements are true for a 2-year-old child? 

 

Statements:

 

  1. The child's weight is four times that of birth weight.
  2. The child can ride a tricycle independently.
  3. The child climbs up and down stairs with alternating steps.
  4. Both upper and lower canines have erupted.
  5. The ossification center for the head of the radius appears.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

 

Statement 1. True – The child's weight is four times that of birth weight.

 

  • At 1 year: The weight is 3 times the birth weight.
  • At 2 years: The weight is 4 times the birth weight.

 

Statement 4. True – Both upper and lower canines have erupted.

 

  • Upper and lower canines typically erupt between 16–20 months of age, so by 2 years, they should be present.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. False – The child can ride a tricycle independently.

 

  • Tricycle riding is a milestone achieved at around 3 years of age.
  • At 2 years, children can run well, kick a ball, and climb stairs but cannot yet ride a tricycle.

 

Statement 3. False – The child climbs up and down stairs with alternating steps.

 

  • At 2 years: Children walk up stairs with a rail, placing both feet on each step ("two-footed gait").
  • At 3 years: They walk up stairs with alternating steps.
  • At 4 years: They can go up and down using alternating steps independently.

 

Statement 5. False – The ossification center for the head of the radius appears.

 

  • The ossification center for the radial head appears between 3–4 years of age, not at 2 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • At 2 years, weight is approximately 4 times the birth weight.
  • Canines usually erupt between 16–20 months, so they are present at 2 years.
  • Tricycle riding (3 years) and climbing stairs with alternating steps (4 years) occur later.
  • Ossification of the radial head occurs between 3–4 years.

questions.text: Craigie’s tube method is used in the microbiology lab to assess which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Motile and nonmotile strains

 

  • The Craigie’s tube method is a classic technique used to evaluate bacterial motility.
  • It relies on a semi-solid agar medium with a capillary (Craigie) tube containing the test organism.
  • Motile organisms migrate from the tube into the surrounding agar, causing visible turbidity; nonmotile organisms do not.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virulent and avirulent strains: Typically assessed by evaluating the presence of toxins or invasiveness, not motility.

 

Option C. Capsulated and noncapsulated strains: Best identified using special stains (e.g., India ink, Quellung reaction), not motility-based methods.

 

Option D. Flagellated and nonflagellated strains: While flagella contribute to motility, Craigie’s method tests for motility, not directly for the presence of flagella. Flagella are visualized by flagella stains or electron microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craigie’s tube method distinguishes motile from nonmotile bacterial strains by observing their ability to spread from a capillary tube into surrounding semi-solid agar.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not seen by the procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle meatus

 

  • The middle meatus is located in the anterior nasal cavity, between the middle turbinate and lateral nasal wall.
  • It is better visualized through anterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy, not posterior rhinoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A, B & D: Posterior rhinoscopy allows visualization of structures in the nasopharynx, including:

 

  • Adenoids – Located in the nasopharynx, commonly seen in pediatric patients.
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates – Inferior, middle, and superior turbinates are partially visualized posteriorly.
  • Opening of the eustachian tube – Found in the lateral nasopharyngeal wall.
  • Fossa of Rosenmüller – A common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Torus tubarius – A cartilaginous ridge near the eustachian tube opening.
  • Posterior border of the nasal septum and soft palate – Can be assessed during the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Posterior rhinoscopy is useful for evaluating nasopharyngeal structures such as adenoids, eustachian tube openings, and the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • Anterior rhinoscopy or endoscopy is required to visualize structures like the middle meatus and frontal recess.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding drugs with high first-pass metabolism is/are correct? 

 

  1. Lignocaine is ineffective orally due to extensive hepatic metabolism after absorption.
  2. Propranolol undergoes significant first-pass metabolism, leading to reduced oral bioavailability.
  3. Glyceryl trinitrate is given sublingually to bypass first-pass metabolism and achieve rapid action.
  4. Drugs with high first-pass metabolism are always preferred orally due to longer duration of action.
  5. High first-pass effect means the drug reaches the systemic circulation unchanged in high concentration.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct

 

1. Lignocaine is ineffective orally due to extensive hepatic metabolism after absorption: Correct, Lignocaine (lidocaine) is subject to extensive first-pass metabolism in the liver, which makes oral administration ineffective. It’s typically given IV for systemic use.

 

2. Propranolol undergoes significant first-pass metabolism, leading to reduced oral bioavailability: Correct, Propranolol also undergoes extensive hepatic metabolism, resulting in low oral bioavailability (~25%). This variability often necessitates dose adjustment.

 

3. Glyceryl trinitrate is given sublingually to bypass first-pass metabolism and achieve rapid action: Correct, Glyceryl trinitrate (nitroglycerin) has high first-pass metabolism. It’s given sublingually to bypass the liver and ensure rapid systemic absorption during anginal attacks.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

4. Drugs with high first-pass metabolism are always preferred orally due to longer duration of action: Incorrect, High first-pass metabolism reduces oral bioavailability, making oral delivery less effective, not preferred. Such drugs often require alternative routes (IV, sublingual, transdermal).

 

5. High first-pass effect means the drug reaches the systemic circulation unchanged in high concentration: Incorrect,A high first-pass effect means that a large portion of the drug is metabolized before reaching systemic circulation, so less of the active drug enters the bloodstream, not more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs with high first-pass metabolism, such as lignocaine, propranolol, and nitroglycerin, undergo significant hepatic breakdown after oral administration. Alternate routes (e.g., IV or sublingual) are often used to bypass the liver and improve bioavailability.

questions.text: In a municipal effort to reduce environmental impacts associated with waste management, public health officials evaluate various disposal methods. Considering the need to minimize groundwater contamination while acknowledging potential negative externalities, which waste disposal method should be prioritized despite its high energy use and air pollution concerns?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incineration

 

  • Incineration is favored in scenarios where reducing groundwater contamination is paramount because it involves the combustion of waste at high temperatures, effectively eliminating leachate that could seep into groundwater. 
  • However, this method is not without drawbacks, as it requires significant energy inputs and can lead to air pollution unless advanced pollution control technologies are employed. These controls are necessary to manage emissions of dioxins, furans, and other harmful pollutants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Composting: While beneficial for organic waste reduction and useful in producing compost, it does not entirely prevent potential leachate production, which could contaminate groundwater.

 

Option B. Sanitary landfill: Although engineered to minimize leachate and gas production, landfills can still pose a risk to groundwater, especially if the underlying barrier systems fail.

 

Option D. Hog feeding: Primarily used for organic waste, this method does little to address non-organic waste components and has minimal impact on groundwater but does not address the broader spectrum of municipal waste management challenges.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Incineration, while energy-intensive and potentially polluting, effectively prevents groundwater contamination from waste disposal, making it a crucial option in areas where groundwater protection is a priority. 
  • Advanced emission controls are necessary to mitigate its environmental impact on air quality.

choices.text: After the aunt has taken the varicella vaccine
After the delivery of the baby

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is diagnosed with varicella. Her pregnant aunt is concerned about the risk of exposure. She asks when she can safely meet the child. When is the earliest that the child can meet her pregnant aunt?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) When the lesions have crusted

 

  • Varicella is highly contagious and spreads via respiratory droplets and direct contact with lesions.
  • The period of communicability starts 1–2 days before the rash appears and lasts until all lesions have crusted over, which typically takes 4–7 days in immunocompetent individuals.
  • Pregnant women are at high risk of complications, including varicella pneumonia and congenital varicella syndrome (if infection occurs in early pregnancy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediately: Incorrect.

 

  • The child is still contagious until all lesions have crusted over. Meeting the aunt immediately could expose her to the virus.

 

Option C. After the aunt has taken the varicella vaccine: Incorrect.

 

  • Varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and is contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • If a non-pregnant woman gets vaccinated, she should avoid pregnancy for at least 1 month.

 

Option D. After the delivery of the baby: Incorrect.

 

  • While avoiding contact until after delivery would completely eliminate risk, it is not necessary. The child can safely meet her aunt once the lesions have crusted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Varicella is contagious from 1–2 days before rash onset until all lesions crust over.
  • Pregnant women are at high risk of severe varicella infection and fetal complications.
  • Isolation should continue until the lesions are completely crusted.
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (VZIG or vaccination) may be considered in high-risk individuals.

questions.text: A volcanic eruption has recently occurred, resulting in significant ash and toxic gas emissions. Public health officials are concerned about the sharp increase in respiratory ailments among the affected population. In this critical situation, at which stage of the disaster cycle should the health team concentrate their efforts to maximize the impact on public health?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Response

 

  • The Response phase of the disaster cycle is crucial in this scenario as it involves immediate actions taken to ensure public safety and health following an emergency. 
  • This stage focuses on emergency services, medical care, and other direct interventions to manage the health crisis effectively, particularly addressing acute respiratory issues caused by the inhalation of volcanic ash and gases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitigation: This stage focuses on measures that reduce the risk of disaster or its impacts but does not deal directly with the immediate effects after a disaster has occurred.

 

Option B. Preparedness: Preparedness involves planning and readiness activities before an event, which, while crucial, are not as directly impactful once a disaster like a volcanic eruption has already occurred.

 

Option D. Recovery: The Recovery phase focuses on returning the community to normal or better conditions post-disaster, which includes long-term health care and rebuilding, but is not aimed at the immediate health crises caused by the eruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the critical importance of the Response phase in the disaster management cycle, particularly in addressing immediate health concerns like respiratory problems following a volcanic eruption. 
  • This knowledge is essential for effectively prioritizing and deploying medical and emergency resources in the aftermath of a disaster.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to generalized seizures, developmental delay, and decreased activity. Examination reveals hypopigmented skin, grayish hair, and a mousy body odor. Urine testing reveals elevated phenylalanine levels. Further evaluation suggests a rare variant of phenylketonuria (PKU) due to a defect unrelated to the primary enzyme. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dihydropterin reductase

 

  • This patient exhibits classic features of PKU: developmental delay, seizures, hypopigmentation, and mousy odor.
  • In rare variants of PKU, the defect is not in phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) itself, but in its required cofactor, tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).
  • Dihydropterin reductase is the enzyme that regenerates BH4.
  • Without BH4, PAH becomes nonfunctional, even if it's structurally intact, leading to hyperphenylalaninemia and neurologic symptoms due to disrupted catecholamine and serotonin synthesis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosinase: Involved in melanin synthesis from tyrosine. Its deficiency causes albinism, not PKU.

 

Option B. Tyrosine kinase: Involved in intracellular signaling, not in amino acid metabolism or PKU pathogenesis.

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency here causes classic PKU, but the question specifies a rare variant, indicating a cofactor-related defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dihydropterin reductase deficiency causes a rare variant of PKU by impairing BH4 regeneration, leading to functional loss of phenylalanine hydroxylase despite normal enzyme structure.

questions.text: Which of the following bacterial toxins increases adenylate cyclase activity via G-protein coupled activation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cholera toxin

 

  • Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, ADP-ribosylates the Gs alpha subunit of G-proteins, locking it in its active form.
  • This leads to persistent activation of adenylate cyclase, causing elevated intracellular cAMP, resulting in massive chloride and water secretion from enterocytes and hence profuse watery diarrhea.
  • This is a classic G-protein mediated mechanism of toxin-induced cellular dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria toxin: Inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor-2 (EF-2). It does not interact with G-proteins or adenylate cyclase.

 

Option B. Shiga toxin: Inhibits the 60S ribosomal subunit, blocking protein synthesis by cleaving rRNA, primarily in intestinal endothelial cells. It does not affect adenylate cyclase or G-proteins.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas exotoxin A: Functions similarly to diphtheria toxin by inhibiting EF-2 and halting protein synthesis. It also has no action on G-protein signaling or cAMP pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cholera toxin increases intracellular cAMP by ADP-ribosylating Gs proteins, activating adenylate cyclase via a G-protein coupled mechanism—leading to severe secretory diarrhea.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient on medical therapy for chronic open-angle glaucoma presents for follow-up after routine tonometry shows persistently elevated intraocular pressure. The ophthalmic examination is otherwise stable. To enhance aqueous humor outflow through the uveoscleral pathway, the current medication regimen is adjusted. Which of the following drugs most specifically facilitates this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin F2α analog that lowers intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor. 
  • It is commonly used in the management of open-angle glaucoma and is one of the most effective agents for long-term IOP reduction.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Increases permeability of the uveoscleral pathway
  • Enhances aqueous humor drainage through the ciliary muscle and surrounding tissues

 

Side effects may include increased iris pigmentation and eyelash growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dorzolamide: A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases aqueous humor production, not outflow. It works by inhibiting the enzyme in the ciliary processes responsible for fluid formation.

 

Option C. Timolol: A non-selective beta-blocker that lowers IOP by reducing aqueous humor production in the ciliary epithelium, not by affecting uveoscleral flow.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: A muscarinic agonist that facilitates aqueous outflow via the trabecular meshwork, not the uveoscleral pathway. It contracts the ciliary muscle and opens the angle in angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latanoprost lowers intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients by enhancing uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor.
  • It is a prostaglandin analog and considered first-line in the chronic management of open-angle glaucoma.

choices.text: Alkaline diuresis increases the renal elimination of salicylate by enhancing its ionization, making it less reabsorbed.
Alkaline diuresis neutralizes the acidic environment in the stomach, reducing salicylate absorption.
Alkaline diuresis increases the metabolic conversion of salicylate into a non-toxic form.
Alkaline diuresis helps to reverse the respiratory alkalosis caused by salicylate toxicity.

questions.text: In the treatment of salicylate poisoning, why is alkaline diuresis commonly employed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alkaline diuresis increases the renal elimination of salicylate by enhancing its ionization, making it less reabsorbed.

 

  • Salicylates are weak acids, and their renal excretion depends on urinary pH. 
  • In an alkaline urine environment, salicylate exists more in its ionized (charged) form, which cannot easily cross renal tubular membranes, and thus is not reabsorbed back into the bloodstream. 
  • This process is called "ion trapping." As a result, more salicylate stays in the urine and is eliminated from the body, which is beneficial in overdose cases.
  • Alkalinization of urine, typically using sodium bicarbonate, enhances this process and is a cornerstone in the management of moderate to severe salicylate poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alkaline diuresis neutralizes the acidic environment in the stomach, reducing salicylate absorption: Incorrect, Alkaline diuresis affects the renal elimination, not the gastric absorption. Reducing gastric absorption is handled through activated charcoal, not urinary alkalinization.

 

Option C. Alkaline diuresis increases the metabolic conversion of salicylate into a non-toxic form: Incorrect, Alkaline diuresis does not alter the metabolism of salicylates. Metabolic pathways are not influenced by urinary pH.

 

Option D. Alkaline diuresis helps to reverse the respiratory alkalosis caused by salicylate toxicity: Incorrect. Salicylate toxicity initially causes respiratory alkalosis, but alkaline diuresis does not correct this. In fact, it addresses metabolic acidosis and promotes excretion, rather than altering respiratory compensation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaline diuresis enhances the renal excretion of salicylates by increasing their ionization in urine, thus reducing reabsorption and aiding in detoxification.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and tremors. Examination shows a diffusely enlarged thyroid with bruit and exophthalmos. Lab evaluation reveals suppressed TSH and elevated T3 and T4. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins are positive. She is scheduled for radioactive iodine ablation (RAIA) therapy. What should be the next appropriate step before initiating RAIA?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start methimazole

 

Patients with Graves’ disease require euthyroid state before RAIA to prevent thyroid storm. Methimazole helps achieve this. Steroids are indicated only if there is significant orbitopathy. Potassium iodide is given just before thyroidectomy, not RAIA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administer potassium iodide: Given preoperatively in surgery, not prior to RAIA.

 

Option C. Start levothyroxine: Used after ablation to treat hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Administer steroids: Used if active orbitopathy is present; not routinely required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methimazole is initiated before RAIA in hyperthyroid patients to prevent thyroid storm by achieving a euthyroid state.

questions.text:
Match the following Rickettsial species with their associated diseases:

 

 

Which of the following is the correct match?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A–3, B–1, C–4, D–2

 

A–3: Rickettsia prowazekii – Epidemic typhus / Brill-Zinsser
Correct, R. prowazekii causes epidemic typhus, a severe louse-borne illness seen in overcrowded or unhygienic conditions. It can relapse years later as Brill-Zinsser disease, a milder reactivation form. This specific association was explicitly mentioned in the document, including both epidemic typhus and Brill (Zinsser) forms.

 

B–1: Rickettsia typhi – Endemic typhus: Correct, R. typhi causes endemic typhus, also called murine typhus, typically transmitted by fleas. The document directly links R. typhi with endemic typhus.

 

C–4: Rickettsia rickettsii – Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF): Correct, RMSF is caused by R. rickettsii, a tick-borne infection that presents with fever, rash, and potential multi-organ failure. The document mentions this association explicitly.

 

D–2: Rickettsia conorii – Indian tick typhus: Correct, Indian tick typhus is caused by R. conorii, and this is directly stated in the source image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

R. prowazekii causes epidemic typhus and Brill-Zinsser disease, R. typhi causes endemic typhus, R. rickettsii causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and R. conorii causes Indian tick typhus — these specific associations must be memorized for accurate diagnosis and understanding of rickettsial infections.

questions.text: BRAVO capsule is used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GERD

 

  • The BRAVO capsule is a wireless pH monitoring device used for the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • It is attached to the esophageal lining during endoscopy and continuously records pH levels for 48 hours to evaluate acid reflux.
  • It helps determine the correlation between symptoms and acid reflux events and guides management decisions.

 

 

Bravo pH capsule system

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Upper GI bleed: The BRAVO capsule is not used for diagnosing upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Endoscopy remains the gold standard for this condition.
 

Option C. Lower GI bleed: Lower GI bleeding is typically evaluated using colonoscopy or capsule endoscopy but not the BRAVO capsule.
 


Option D. Obscure GI bleed: Obscure GI bleeding is investigated using capsule endoscopy or enteroscopy, depending on the suspected source. BRAVO is not relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BRAVO capsule is a minimally invasive diagnostic tool specifically designed for evaluating GERD through continuous esophageal pH monitoring. 
  • It plays no role in diagnosing GI bleeding.

choices.text: Annual count of hospital admissions related to Typhoid Fever.
Yearly community survey assessing water usage and sanitation habits.
Analysis of antibiotic resistance trends in identified Typhoid Fever cases.
Routine screening of food handlers for Typhoid carriers.

questions.text: In an urban public health campaign focused on minimizing Typhoid Fever incidence, which metric would be most useful for evaluating the initiative's success?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yearly community survey assessing water usage and sanitation habits.

 

  • The most effective strategy to gauge the success of a public health initiative aimed at curtailing Typhoid Fever, which primarily spreads through contaminated water and poor sanitation, is conducting a yearly community survey on water usage and sanitation practices. 
  • This approach directly targets the environmental factors that facilitate the transmission of the disease, providing actionable data that can lead to targeted interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual count of hospital admissions related to Typhoid Fever: Monitoring hospital admissions offers data on severe cases but does not provide insight into overall disease prevalence or the effectiveness of preventative measures.

 

Option C. Analysis of antibiotic resistance trends in identified Typhoid Fever cases: While evaluating antibiotic resistance patterns is crucial for treatment strategies, it does not directly assess the impact of preventative public health measures.

 

Option D. Routine screening of food handlers for Typhoid carriers: Regular screening of food handlers can help reduce some transmission routes but doesn't address the primary transmission mechanism through contaminated water.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • For public health initiatives aimed at controlling diseases like Typhoid Fever, which is primarily transmitted through contaminated water, the most effective evaluation method focuses on monitoring and improving environmental and sanitary conditions. 
  • Surveys assessing water usage and sanitation practices provide direct insights into the root causes of the disease and the effectiveness of the interventions applied.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a 10-year history of ulcerative colitis presents with fatigue and pruritus. Liver function tests reveal markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), with near-normal bilirubin and aminotransferases. MRCP is done and it is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

 

PSC commonly occurs in patients with inflammatory bowel disease, especially ulcerative colitis. Elevated ALP and GGT with cholestatic pattern and multiple strictures on MRCP confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary biliary cholangitis: Typically affects women and shows AMA positivity.

 

Option B. Autoimmune hepatitis: Shows elevated transaminases, not cholestasis.

 

Option D. Cancer of the pancreatic head: Would present with obstructive jaundice and mass lesion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

PSC should be suspected in IBD patients with cholestatic LFTs and confirmed by MRCP showing multifocal strictures.

questions.text:
Match List I (Adult Structures) with List II (Corresponding Embryonic Origin).

 

List I (Adult Structures)

 

  1. Gartner’s duct
  2. Round ligament
  3. Lower vagina
  4. Clitoris

 

List II (Embryonic Origin)

 

  1. Mesonephric duct
  2. Gubernaculum
  3. Genital ridge
  4. Genital tubercle
  5. Müllerian duct
  6. Urogenital sinus
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-6, D-4

 

A-1. Gartner’s duct → Mesonephric duct:

 

  • Gartner’s duct is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct, found in females along the vaginal walls.
  • In males, the Wolffian duct gives rise to the epididymis, vas deferens, and seminal vesicles.

 

B-2. Round ligament → Gubernaculum:

 

  • The round ligament is derived from the gubernaculum, which in males becomes the gubernaculum testis guiding testicular descent.
  • In females, it helps maintain uterine position by connecting the uterus to the labia majora.

 

C-6. Lower vagina → Urogenital sinus:

 

  • The lower vagina develops from the urogenital sinus, while the upper part originates from the Müllerian duct.
  • The urogenital sinus also forms the bladder, urethra, and vestibule of the vagina.

 

D-4. Clitoris → Genital tubercle:

 

  • The clitoris is derived from the genital tubercle, which also forms the penis in males.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gartner’s duct is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in females.
  • The round ligament originates from the gubernaculum, aiding uterine support.
  • The lower vagina forms from the urogenital sinus, while the upper part is from the Müllerian duct.
  • The genital tubercle differentiates into the clitoris in females and the penis in males.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with no known past medical history suddenly collapses while jogging. He is pronounced dead at the scene. Family history reveals that his father also died suddenly in his 30s. Autopsy reveals a markedly thickened interventricular septum, and histologic examination of the myocardium is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

 

  • The image shows classic features of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), including:
    • Myocyte hypertrophy
    • Disorganized (disarrayed) cardiac fibers
    • Interstitial fibrosis

 

HCM is a genetic disorder (often autosomal dominant) involving mutations in sarcomere proteins, such as beta-myosin heavy chain or myosin-binding protein C. It is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes due to ventricular arrhythmias triggered by myocardial disarray and fibrosis.

 

The clinical context of sudden cardiac death and the histologic appearance match hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, making this the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endocardial fibroelastosis: Incorrect, A rare pediatric condition presenting with thickening of the endocardium due to fibroelastic tissue proliferation. Does not cause myocyte disarray or septal hypertrophy as seen in HCM.

 

Option B. Rhabdomyoma: Incorrect, Common in infants and children, especially with tuberous sclerosis. Histology shows “spider cells”—large cells with radial cytoplasmic strands—not hypertrophied and disarrayed cardiomyocytes.

 

Option C. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Incorrect, Shows dilated ventricular chambers, myocyte atrophy, and interstitial fibrosis, without the myocyte hypertrophy and disarray seen in HCM.


Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic myocardial disorder characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, myofiber disarray, and interstitial fibrosis. It is a common cause of sudden cardiac death in young individuals, particularly during exertion.

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? 

 

  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

 

Branches of the Internal Iliac Artery:

 

  • The internal iliac artery is the major artery supplying the pelvis.
  • It divides into anterior and posterior divisions:

 

Branches of the Anterior Division:

 

All correct options belong to this division

 

  1. Obturator artery
  2. Superior vesical artery 
  3. Inferior vesical artery 
  4. Inferior gluteal artery 
  5. Middle rectal artery 
  6. Vaginal artery (in females) 
  7. Uterine artery (in females)
  8. Internal pudendal artery


Branches of the Posterior Division of the Internal Iliac Artery:

 

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The internal iliac artery supplies most of the pelvic structures and divides into anterior and posterior divisions.
  • The anterior division supplies pelvic organs (bladder, rectum, reproductive structures) and gluteal/perineal regions.
  • The posterior division mainly supplies the pelvic walls and gluteal muscles.
  • The superior gluteal artery is a posterior division branch, while the inferior gluteal artery is from the anterior division.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man who recently returned from rural India presents with a 2-month history of intermittent fever, weight loss, and abdominal fullness. On physical examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly and pallor. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages filled with amastigotes. What is the most appropriate first-line pharmacologic treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B


This patient presents with visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), a protozoal infection caused by the Leishmania donovani complex, which is endemic in rural India and other tropical regions. Key features include:

 

  • Prolonged intermittent fever
  • Weight loss
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pancytopenia (due to bone marrow infiltration)
  • Amastigotes within macrophages on bone marrow or splenic aspirate

 

The most effective and recommended first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis, particularly in India, is liposomal Amphotericin B. It has a high efficacy rate, improved safety profile, and is WHO-recommended for treatment in endemic areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Incorrect. Ivermectin is used to treat helminthic infections such as onchocerciasis and strongyloidiasis, not protozoal diseases like leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Pentavalent antimonials (e.g., sodium stibogluconate): These were historically used for leishmaniasis, but resistance in India is high, and they have more toxicity compared to Amphotericin B. They are no longer first-line in Indian subcontinent settings.

 

Option D. Albendazole: Albendazole is an anti-helminthic agent, commonly used for giardiasis, ascariasis, echinococcosis, and neurocysticercosis. It has no role in the treatment of Leishmania species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) should be suspected in patients with prolonged fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia returning from endemic areas like rural India. The first-line treatment is liposomal Amphotericin B.

choices.text: Drug is an instant release preparation
The standards according to Indian Pharmacopoeia
Product complies with international patent norms

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of bronchial asthma is prescribed a tablet formulation of Salbutamol Sulphate. The packaging label includes the abbreviation “IP” next to the drug name, as shown in the image. What does “IP” most accurately indicate in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The standards according to Indian Pharmacopoeia

 

  • The abbreviation IP on a drug label stands for Indian Pharmacopoeia. 
  • It signifies that the formulation, strength, purity, and quality of the drug meet the official standards set by the Indian Pharmacopoeia Commission, which are legally binding in India under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act.
  •  Inclusion of "IP" ensures that the medication is manufactured and tested according to these regulatory standards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug is an instant release preparation:  Incorrect, the term “instant release” is typically indicated by labels such as IR, not “IP”.

 

Option B. Meant for intra pulmonary use: Incorrect. “IP” does not refer to route of administration. Salbutamol can be delivered via various routes (oral, inhaled), but “IP” does not imply “intrapulmonary”.

 

Option D. Product complies with international patent norms: Incorrect, “IP” is unrelated to patent protection. It refers only to pharmacopoeial standards, not intellectual property or patent status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abbreviation “IP” on a drug label indicates that the formulation complies with the standards set by the Indian Pharmacopoeia, ensuring quality, identity, and purity of the pharmaceutical product.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female visits the clinic for cervical cancer prevention counseling. She is advised to receive the nonavalent HPV vaccine, which provides protection against multiple high-risk Human Papillomavirus (HPV) strains associated with cervical, vulvar, vaginal, and anal cancers, as well as genital warts. Which of the following HPV strains are covered by the nonavalent HPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58


The nonavalent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) protects against nine HPV types, including:

 

  • High-risk oncogenic types (associated with cervical and anogenital cancers): 
    • HPV  16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58
  • Low-risk types (linked to genital warts and other lesions): 
    • HPV 6, 11

 

This expanded coverage offers greater protection against cervical, vaginal, vulvar, anal cancers, and genital warts compared to the bivalent (HPV 16, 18) and quadrivalent (HPV 6, 11, 16, 18) vaccines.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • HPV vaccination is essential for preventing cervical and anogenital cancers and genital warts.
  • The nonavalent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) covers 9 HPV types (16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58, 6, and 11).
  • Cervarix is effective against 16 and 18
  • Gardasil and Cervavac are effective against 6,11,16 and 18
  • HPV 16 and 18 are the most oncogenic types, responsible for the majority of cervical cancer cases.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion
Assertion is true, but Reason is false
Assertion is false, but Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Secondary amyloidosis commonly develops in patients with long-standing chronic inflammatory diseases due to deposition of AA amyloid in organs.


Reason (R): Serum amyloid A (SAA) is produced by hepatocytes in response to interleukin-6 during acute infections.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion

 

  • Assertion: True,
    Secondary amyloidosis involves systemic AA amyloid deposition that typically follows chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis, or Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF).
  • Reason: True,
    SAA is indeed synthesized by hepatocytes in response to cytokines, particularly IL-6, and is elevated during acute infections. However, acute infections alone rarely lead to AA amyloidosis because short-term SAA elevation is insufficient. It's the persistent elevation in chronic inflammation that leads to amyloidogenic transformation of SAA.
  • Thus, while both statements are factually correct, the Reason does not adequately explain the Assertion, because it focuses on acute rather than chronic inflammatory processes, which are central to the development of secondary amyloidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary (AA) amyloidosis arises from prolonged elevation of SAA during chronic inflammation, while transient increases during acute infections do not typically lead to amyloid deposition.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis from the images shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Turner Syndrome

 

Turner syndrome (45, X) is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It presents with distinctive clinical features:

 

Image A. Webbed Neck: Due to cystic hygroma in fetal life, leading to excess skin folds on the neck.

 

Image B. Low Posterior Hairline: A typical finding in Turner syndrome.

 

Image C. Shield-Shaped Chest with Widely Spaced Nipples: Common skeletal anomaly.

 

Images D & E. Lymphedema of Hands and Feet: Due to lymphatic obstruction, leading to puffy hands and feet at birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Noonan Syndrome: Noonan syndrome also presents with webbed neck and widely spaced nipples, but it affects both males and females and is associated with pulmonary stenosis, short stature, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia: A skeletal dysplasia characterized by short limbs, frontal bossing, and midface hypoplasia, but does not present with webbed neck or lymphedema.

 

Option D. Down Syndrome: Features include flat facial profile, epicanthal folds, hypotonia, and single palmar crease, but not webbed neck or lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Turner Syndrome (45, X) is a chromosomal disorder affecting females with characteristic webbed neck, low posterior hairline, shield-shaped chest, and congenital lymphedema.
  • It differs from Noonan syndrome, which can affect both sexes, and from other genetic conditions like Achondroplasia and Down Syndrome.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with karyotyping (45, X), and management includes growth hormone therapy and estrogen replacement.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with shortness of breath and right-sided chest discomfort. He reports progressive dyspnea over the past week. Chest imaging is performed, and the radiograph is shown below. Based on this finding, which of the following would most likely be observed on physical examination over the right lower chest?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased tactile fremitus

 

  • The chest X-ray demonstrates a right-sided pleural effusion, indicated by a dense homogenous opacity with a classic meniscus sign and blunting of the right costophrenic angle. 
  • In pleural effusion, fluid accumulates in the pleural space, which acts as a barrier between the lung and chest wall.
  • On physical examination over the area of effusion, tactile fremitus is decreased or absent because vibrations from the voice are dampened by the fluid. Likewise, breath sounds are reduced, and dullness to percussion is typically found due to the liquid medium. 
  • These findings help differentiate pleural effusion from other pulmonary pathologies.


Other Options: 

 

Option A. Increased resonance on percussion: This is characteristic of conditions with air accumulation, such as pneumothorax, not fluid. Pleural effusion causes dullness, not hyperresonance.

 

Option B. Bronchial breath sounds: These are typically heard over areas of consolidation, such as in lobar pneumonia, where the lung tissue becomes solid and transmits breath sounds better. They are not found over fluid-filled pleural spaces.

 

Option D. Fine inspiratory crackles: Crackles are usually associated with interstitial lung diseases or pulmonary edema, reflecting fluid within the alveoli or interstitial space, not outside the lung as in pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleural effusion reduces tactile fremitus due to fluid dampening sound transmission from the lung to the chest wall.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not explain A
A is true, R is false
A is false, R is true

questions.text:
Assertion–Reason


Assertion (A):
Zuranolone is effective in the treatment of postpartum depression and acts rapidly within days.


Reason (R):
Zuranolone is a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors, acting on both synaptic and extrasynaptic subtypes.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R explains A

 

  • Assertion (A) is true: Zuranolone is a novel drug approved for the treatment of postpartum depression (PPD) and has shown rapid onset of action, often within a few days — a significant advantage over traditional antidepressants, which may take weeks.
  • Reason (R) is also true and explains the assertion: Zuranolone is a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission. Unlike conventional benzodiazepines, zuranolone acts on both synaptic and extrasynaptic GABA-A receptors, which may contribute to its broad and sustained anxiolytic and antidepressant effects, thus explaining its rapid efficacy in PPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zuranolone is a newly approved oral medication for postpartum depression, notable for its rapid onset and GABAergic mechanism of action. 
  • It works as a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors, influencing both phasic (synaptic) and tonic (extrasynaptic) inhibition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with intermittent episodes of right upper abdominal pain. On physical examination, her abdomen is normal. A routine abdominal ultrasound reveals multiple tiny gallbladder calculi. Laboratory investigations show a direct bilirubin level of 2.4 mg% and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MRCP

 

  • The patient's presentation with cholelithiasis, deranged liver function tests (elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase), and an otherwise normal abdominal examination raises suspicion of a common bile duct (CBD) stone (choledocholithiasis). 
  • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a non-invasive imaging modality that is ideal for assessing the biliary tree and confirming the presence of CBD stones before proceeding to more invasive diagnostic or therapeutic procedures like ERCP.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ERCP: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is typically reserved for confirmed CBD stones or therapeutic intervention. It is not the first-line diagnostic tool due to its invasive nature and associated complications (e.g., pancreatitis).
 

Option B. Antibiotics followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While antibiotics and elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy are appropriate for uncomplicated cholelithiasis or mild cholecystitis, the elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase suggest possible CBD involvement, necessitating further investigation before surgery.
 

Option C. HIDA Scan: Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan is used to assess gallbladder function and cystic duct patency. It is not useful for evaluating CBD stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with suspected choledocholithiasis (deranged liver function tests and cholelithiasis), MRCP is the preferred non-invasive diagnostic test to evaluate the biliary tree for CBD stones. 
  • Invasive procedures like ERCP are reserved for confirmed diagnoses or therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: Total Goitre Rate (TGR) in children aged 6-12 years
Median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women
Proportion of households using adequately iodized salt

questions.text: A public health official is assessing the effectiveness of a salt iodization program in a rural community. Which indicator would be most appropriate for early detection of changes in the community's iodine status?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women

 

  • Median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women are a direct and sensitive indicator of iodine status in a community, especially during pregnancy when the demand for iodine is increased to support fetal development. 
  • This measurement provides immediate data on the iodine intake of a highly vulnerable subgroup, making it an excellent early indicator of the effectiveness of iodization programs.


Other Options: 

 

Option A. Total Goitre Rate (TGR) in children aged 6-12 years: This is a useful indicator for assessing long-term iodine status in a community, but changes in goitre rate might not reflect recent improvements in iodine status due to the lag between iodine intake and goitre reduction.

 

Option C. Proportion of households using adequately iodized salt: While this is an important process indicator, it does not directly measure biological iodine status and may not accurately reflect iodine intake if there are issues with the bioavailability of iodine from the salt or adherence to iodized salt usage.

 

Option D. Prevalence of neonatal hypothyroidism: Although important, this indicator might lag behind actual changes in community iodine status and typically requires robust newborn screening programs to detect effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of monitoring the effectiveness of iodine supplementation programs, median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women provide a quick and reliable measure of current iodine status, crucial for early intervention and adjustment of public health strategies. 
  • This indicator helps public health officials to act swiftly in adjusting iodization levels to prevent iodine deficiency disorders in the community.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is admitted to the NICU with progressive lethargy, rapid breathing, and poor feeding. Physical examination reveals hypothermia and signs of cerebral edema. Labs show a markedly low blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and elevated plasma ammonia. Urinalysis is notable for increased orotic acid and glutamine levels, with no evidence of hypoglycemia. The infant develops coma shortly after admission. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mitochondrial ornithine transcarbamoylase

 

  • This clinical scenario is consistent with a urea cycle disorder, specifically ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) deficiency, which is:
  • The most common inherited urea cycle disorder.
  • X-linked recessive, presenting early in neonates, typically males.

Characterized by:

  • Low BUN due to failure of ammonia conversion into urea.
  • Hyperammonemia, which explains the neurological symptoms (coma, cerebral edema).
  • Elevated orotic acid in the urine: excess mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate leaks into the cytoplasm and enters the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, producing orotic acid.
  • Glutamine elevation occurs due to ammonia detoxification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cytoplasmic orotidylate decarboxylase: Deficiency causes orotic aciduria without hyperammonemia or low BUN. No CNS involvement or coma in the neonatal period.

 

Option C. Mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I: Also presents with hyperammonemia, but no orotic acid in the urine. The defect is upstream of orotic acid production.

 

Option D. Cytoplasmic argininosuccinate synthetase: Causes citrullinemia, with elevated citrulline levels and no orotic aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a mitochondrial enzyme defect that leads to neonatal hyperammonemia, low BUN, elevated orotic acid, and coma due to impaired urea cycle function.

questions.text: A 42-year-old farmer presents with fever, weight loss, and nonproductive cough. Chest imaging reveals patchy pulmonary infiltrates. A fungal infection is suspected. A biopsy sample cultured at different temperatures reveals yeast cells at 37°C and mold (hyphal) forms at 25°C. Which of the following organisms most likely exhibits this temperature-dependent morphological change?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Histoplasma capsulatum

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that exists in mold (hyphal) form at 25°C and converts to yeast form at 37°C.
  • This temperature-dependent conversion is a hallmark of dimorphism seen in systemic fungal pathogens.
  • Histoplasma is endemic in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys and commonly causes pulmonary disease, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
  • On histopathology, the yeast forms are often found within macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans: This encapsulated yeast is not dimorphic. It exists solely in the yeast form at all temperatures and is detected using India ink or mucicarmine stain. Commonly causes meningitis in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option C. Malassezia furfur: This lipophilic yeast is associated with tinea versicolor and does not exhibit thermal dimorphism. It appears as spaghetti-and-meatball appearance on KOH prep, not yeast/mold at varying temperatures.

 

Option D. Aspergillus flavus: A mold only; not dimorphic. Causes invasive aspergillosis, aspergillomas, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). Does not show yeast-to-mold transformation with temperature change. Usually affects immunocompromised individuals, but is not cultured as yeast at 37°C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that exists in mold form at 25°C and yeast form at 37°C. This thermal dimorphism is critical for its pathogenicity and helps differentiate it from other fungi

choices.text: McKeown’s approach: Abdomen + Right thorax + Neck approach
Trans-hiatal approach of Orringer: Abdomen + Neck approach
Lewis-Tanner approach: Right Thoracic + Abdominal approach

questions.text: Which of these is not a correctly matched approach for esophageal surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sweet esophagectomy: Right thoracic approach

 

  • Sweet oesophagectomy. Via a single posterolateral incision on the left chest wall (usually fifth to sixth intercostal space), the oesophagus is mobilised. 
  • The diaphragm is opened and the gastroplasty prepared from this opening. 
  • The stomach is delivered to the left thoracic cavity for anastomosis. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. McKeown’s approach: Abdomen + Right thorax + Neck approach: This consists of the mobilisation of the thoracic oesophagus and lymphadenectomy via a thoracotomy (usually right side), followed by abdominal and neck incisions for preparation of the oesophageal substitute (usually the stomach) and its delivery to the neck for a cervical anastomosis. 

 

Option B. Trans-hiatal approach of Orringer: Abdomen + Neck approach: Through a cervical and abdominal approach, the oesophagus is mobilised via both directions, being stripped out bluntly from its mediastinal bed. The gastric conduit is delivered to the neck for cervical anastomosis

 

Option C. Lewis-Tanner approach: Right Thoracic + Abdominal approach: This is a two-phase oesophagectomy consisting of laparotomy for gastric mobilisation and tubularisation, followed by thoracotomy for oesophageal resection. The gastroplasty is delivered into the right thoracic cavity for an oesophago-gastrostomy near the apex of the chest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the esophagus spans different body cavities, various approaches are required for its resection, depending on the extent of resection planned.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male reports persistent posterior knee discomfort and localized swelling over the past two weeks. He denies any trauma or systemic symptoms. MRI of the knee is given below. Based on this imaging and clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Baker’s cyst

 

  • A Baker’s cyst (also known as a popliteal cyst) is a fluid-filled distension of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa that communicates with the knee joint. 
  • It typically appears on MRI as a well-circumscribed hyperintense (bright) lesion in the popliteal region on T2-weighted imaging.
  • In this 25-year-old patient with subacute posterior knee pain and swelling, the MRI findings are classic for a Baker’s cyst, especially its location between the medial gastrocnemius and semimembranosus tendon. 
  • These cysts are often secondary to intra-articular pathology, such as meniscal tears or arthritis, but can also occur in isolation.


Other Options: 

 

Option A. ACL avulsion: This involves detachment of the anterior cruciate ligament from its bony insertion, often due to trauma, especially in young athletes. MRI would typically show disruption of the ACL fibers or bone fragments — not a smooth, cystic structure in the popliteal fossa.

 

Option B. Reactive synovitis: This condition refers to inflammation of the synovium, often after infection or trauma, and presents with joint effusion and diffuse synovial thickening on imaging, not a localized cystic lesion behind the knee.

 

Option D. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis: Typically seen in children under age 16, not in a 25-year-old adult. It presents with joint swelling, morning stiffness, and systemic symptoms. Imaging may show synovial hypertrophy or joint space narrowing but not an isolated popliteal cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Baker’s cyst presents as a fluid-filled lesion in the popliteal fossa, typically located between the medial gastrocnemius and semimembranosus tendon, and is best visualized on MRI.

choices.text: Initiate screening with a high-sensitivity test, followed by a high-specificity test only for those who test positive.
Simultaneously apply two high-sensitivity tests to all individuals, confirming disease only if both tests are positive.
Implement a single high-specificity test and retest only those who test positive with another high-specificity test.
Deploy a single high-sensitivity test and accept its results without subsequent confirmation to maximize resource efficiency.

questions.text: In managing a screening program for a newly emerging viral infection in a rural area with limited healthcare resources, the public health team faces a dilemma in test selection due to the economic burden of false positives. Given the population's low disease prevalence and the high cost of follow-up confirmatory tests, which testing strategy should the team employ to ensure the highest diagnostic accuracy while minimizing unnecessary follow-ups?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiate screening with a high-sensitivity test, followed by a high-specificity test only for those who test positive.

 

  • offers a strategic approach by initially utilizing a high-sensitivity test to ensure that most infected individuals are identified (few false negatives), followed by a high-specificity test for those who initially tested positive, which significantly reduces false positives by confirming the disease presence. 
  • This series testing method is optimal in low-prevalence areas as it minimizes the economic impact of follow-up and unnecessary treatments by ensuring that only those most likely to be infected undergo costly and resource-intensive confirmatory testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Simultaneously apply two high-sensitivity tests to all individuals, confirming disease only if both tests are positive: This parallel testing strategy increases sensitivity but is not optimal for minimizing false positives, which can be high with two sensitivity-focused tests, potentially leading to unnecessary confirmatory procedures.

 

Option C. Implement a single high-specificity test and retest only those who test positive with another high-specificity test: While this approach seems effective, it may miss initial cases due to the first test's potentially lower sensitivity, crucial in controlling a newly emerging infection.

 

Option D. Deploy a single high-sensitivity test and accept its results without subsequent confirmation to maximize resource efficiency: This method risks a high rate of false positives due to the lack of a confirmatory step, leading to possible overtreatment and misallocation of limited healthcare resources.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In public health screening, especially for low-prevalence conditions, strategically sequencing tests—starting with a high-sensitivity test followed by a high-specificity test for positives—effectively enhances diagnostic accuracy while minimizing the economic and logistical burdens of false positives.
  • This approach optimizes the use of resources in constrained settings and ensures that only the most likely positive cases undergo expensive and resource-intensive confirmatory testing.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is evaluated for changes in appearance and metabolism. He reports that over the last year he has noticed his shoes and gloves no longer fit, and others have commented on his coarsened facial features. He also reports excessive sweating and has been recently diagnosed with impaired glucose tolerance. On examination, enlargement of the hands, feet, and jaw (chin protrusion) is observed. MRI reveals a pituitary macroadenoma. Which of the following medications acts as a growth hormone receptor antagonist and is appropriate for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pegvisomant

 

  • This patient has classic signs of acromegaly, caused by excess secretion of growth hormone (GH) from a pituitary adenoma. 
  • The clinical features—chin protrusion, hand and foot enlargement, excessive sweating, and glucose intolerance—are hallmark signs.
  • Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist. 
  • It blocks the peripheral actions of GH by preventing GH from binding to its receptor, thereby reducing IGF-1 levels (insulin-like growth factor-1), which mediate many of GH's effects. 
  • It is particularly effective in normalizing IGF-1 in patients with acromegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Topiramate: This is an anticonvulsant that modulates voltage-gated sodium channels and GABA activity. It has no role in GH regulation or acromegaly treatment.

 

Option C. Octreotide: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog that inhibits GH secretion from the pituitary. While effective, it is not a GH receptor antagonist. The question specifically asks for a drug that blocks GH receptor function.

 

Option D. Bromocriptine: Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that may modestly lower GH in some patients but is not as effective as pegvisomant or somatostatin analogs. It is not a GH receptor antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly to reduce IGF-1 levels by blocking peripheral GH signaling.
